Only three of the pictures (A, B, and C) are girls. From the clues:
- Blonde hair: narrows it to A or C (B has brown/red hair).
- Doesn’t wear glasses: eliminates A (A is wearing glasses).
- Mole under her right eye: C is the only remaining candidate and she has a small beauty mark under the eye on the right side of her face (her right, not necessarily the viewer’s right).
So the best friend must be C.

Only floors above the ground floor contain guest rooms, and every window on those floors belongs to exactly one room. Since each room has 2 windows, the total number of rooms equals (total guest-room windows) ÷ 2.

Because all four sides have an identical layout, we can count the windows on one side and multiply by 4.

On one side, above the ground floor, there are:
- 3 full guest floors with 4 windows each: 3 × 4 = 12 windows
- 1 top guest floor with 2 windows: 2 windows
So that side has 12 + 2 = 14 guest-room windows.

All four sides together have 4 × 14 = 56 guest-room windows. With 2 windows per room, the hotel has 56 ÷ 2 = 28 guest rooms in total.

Look at how the “empty space” under the top surface changes across the row.

- Shape **1** is a solid block (no opening).
- Shape **2** has **one opening** cut out from underneath on one side (so it looks like a block with a single “gap”/cutaway).
- Shape **3** has **two openings** under the top (the cutaway has expanded, leaving more separated “legs”).
- After reaching this maximum in the middle, the pattern reverses: the openings should reduce back down.
- Therefore shape **4** must return to **one opening**, but it has to be the **mirror/opposite side** of shape 2 so that the sequence can finish at shape **5** as a solid block again.

Among A, B, and C, only **C** shows the single under-cut opening on the opposite side (the mirrored version of shape 2). A and B have different cut patterns (not a single mirrored cutaway), so they don’t fit the expand-then-contract sequence.

answer: The central stair/hall room that connects the left and right wings of the suite (the narrow room in the middle).
justification:
Treat each room as a node in a graph, with doorways as connections. The staff want a route that visits every room exactly once (no doubling back), i.e., a Hamiltonian path through this graph.

In the floor plan, the narrow central room with the stairs (the one between the left wing and the right wing) is the only connection between the two halves of the suite. If you remove that room, the suite splits into two disconnected groups of rooms (left wing and right wing). That makes it a “cut” room: any non-repeating route that covers the entire suite can pass through it only once, because passing from one wing to the other requires going through it, and revisiting it would violate the no-doubling-back rule.

Moreover, each wing contains the same number of rooms. So whether the staff clean the left wing first or the right wing first, they must finish exactly half the suite, then go through this central stair room to reach the other half. That forces this room to occur at the same position (the midpoint) in every valid route.

Luke’s order costs twice as much as the professor’s. Since every item shown was ordered by one of them, split the 7 prices into two groups (Luke vs. Professor) with Luke’s total = 2 × Professor’s total.

Add all prices: 8 + 12 + 13 + 14 + 16 + 17 + 25 = 105.
So if Professor = P and Luke = 2P, then P + 2P = 105 → 3P = 105 → P = 35 and Luke = 70.

Now find a subset of the prices that sums to 70:
25 + 17 + 16 + 12 = 70.
The remaining items (8 + 13 + 14 = 35) match the professor’s total, confirming the split is correct.

Therefore, the items in Luke’s order are the ones priced 12, 16, 17, and 25.

The numbers are formed by **counting the straight wooden bars** that make up each symbol:

- The **first digit** is the number of **vertical** bars.
- The **second digit** is the number of **horizontal** bars.

This matches the given examples:
- **A = 63** because symbol A is made from **6 vertical** bars and **3 horizontal** bars.
- **B = 89** because symbol B is made from **8 vertical** bars and **9 horizontal** bars.

Now count symbol **C**:
- It has **5 vertical** bars (left border, two edges of the wide pane, the left edge of the thin pane, and the right border).
- It has **2 horizontal** bars (top and bottom).

So C corresponds to **52**.

Each shape in the top row is made from a number of identical small cubes. Counting them from left to right gives a clear countdown: the first block is made of 4 cubes, the next is 3 cubes, and the next is 2 cubes. To continue the pattern, the missing block must therefore be made of 1 cube. Among choices A–D, only block **B** is a single cube, so it’s the only one that completes the sequence (revealing the “4-3-2-1” message).

Because each bear eats from one end (head or tail) and must eat at least a little, any fish that was eaten will be missing at least part of its head end or tail end. A fish that is still completely intact therefore must not have been touched by any bear.

In the picture, 3 of the remaining fish are completely whole (no end missing). That means at least 3 of the original 10 fish were not eaten at all, so at most 10 − 3 = 7 fish could have been eaten (one per bear).

This maximum is achievable: 7 bears each take one fish; the fish that are shown with an end missing are the ones two bears didn’t finish, while the other 5 bears finish their fish completely, leaving nothing behind.

The markings on the finished toy show that each visible face is made up of four smaller squares (a 2×2 face), with the symbol split across those four squares. That means the whole cube is a 2×2×2 cube, i.e., it is built from 8 small cubes.

So the correct selection must be a set of pieces whose total “block count” is exactly 8 and which can physically fit within a 2×2×2 boundary.

- **B** is an L‑shaped piece of **3** small cubes.
- **D** is also an L‑shaped piece of **3** small cubes.
- **E** is a straight **2**‑cube piece.

Together they total **3 + 3 + 2 = 8**, exactly the full cube. Their painted symbol fragments can be arranged to complete each 2×2 symbol face and still allow the opposite face to be an identical copy.

The remaining pieces (**A** and **C**) cannot both be part of the cube because including either forces the remaining volume/shape to be wrong for a 2×2×2 cube (you can’t complete the cube cleanly to 8 unit cubes while keeping the required face patterns).

answer: A baby (the fetus) in the lower abdomen.
justification: On the X-ray there’s more than just the outline of a pair of scissors: in the lower abdomen you can make out the distinct shape of a curled-up baby (a fetal silhouette/skeleton). Layton’s point is that, compared to the lost scissors, discovering you’re carrying a baby is the far bigger surprise and the real thing to worry about.

The helmet is dented inward at the top. If someone put it on *without changing what they’re wearing*, then whatever is on their head right now had to fit under the helmet—and would be what pushed the metal in.

Among the four, only **D** has a large, rigid-looking “obstacle” on top of his head (that tall, spiky hair), and he’s also holding his head as if it’s sore from having a dented helmet pressed down onto it. The others either have softer headwear/hair (a hat/cap or curls) that wouldn’t plausibly dent the metal in the same way and show no sign of discomfort.

So the lad who wore the armor and caused the dent is **D**.

From the picture there are 6 bowls: the first three are pork noodles and the last three are plain noodles (PPP NNN).

They must stay in the same 6 evenly spaced spots, so the goal is to make the *types* alternate across those fixed positions. The best alternating pattern to aim for is:

Pork, Plain, Pork, Plain, Pork, Plain.

Comparing this target with the current line:
- Positions 1, 3, 4, and 6 already match.
- Only positions 2 and 5 are wrong (they are Pork and Plain respectively, but should be Plain and Pork).

So we just swap the bowls in positions 2 and 5. Since moving each bowl counts as one move (and a swap counts as two moves), that takes 2 moves total. You can’t do it in 1 move because at least two positions are wrong, meaning at least two bowls must change places.

Label the six faces by their symbols: Star (green), Square (purple), Sun (blue), Heart (red), Diamond (red), and the Grey dotted face.

From boxes A and C, the Star is shown touching Square and Sun (A) and also touching Heart and Diamond (C). A face touches four others on a cube, so the only face the Star does *not* touch must be its opposite: therefore **Star is opposite the Grey dotted face**.

From boxes A and D, the Square is shown touching Star and Sun (A) and also touching the Grey dotted face and Diamond (D). That’s again four neighbours, so the only remaining face (Heart) must be opposite the Square: **Square is opposite Heart**. This leaves the last opposite pair as **Sun opposite Diamond**.

Now fix an orientation using A: Top=Star, Front=Square, Right=Sun. Then the forced opposite faces are Bottom=Grey, Back=Heart, Left=Diamond.
With that cube, if you rotate it so the Square becomes the top, the Grey face becomes the front (this is a simple forward tilt), the **right** face stays the Sun. So the view must be (Top Square, Front Grey, Right Sun).

But box **D** shows (Top Square, Front Grey, Right Diamond). That would require swapping left/right (a mirror image), which can’t be obtained by rotating the same cube. Therefore D is the odd one out.

“Those who have faced it in battle” hints that you shouldn’t look at the sword from the side (as pictured), but imagine looking straight at it from the opponent’s point of view—end‑on, down the blade.

Only one of these swords would present a diamond (♦) shape when viewed head‑on: the top sword is a straight, double‑edged blade with a raised central ridge, i.e., a typical diamond cross‑section. From the front, that cross‑section looks like a single diamond—an “ace” (one) of diamonds.

The middle blade looks flat and slab‑like (more rectangular), and the bottom is a curved, single‑edged style that wouldn’t form a diamond when faced.

So the legendary “Ace of Diamonds” is the top sword.

Treat the 3×3 chart as a “follow the arrow” grid: from any square you move one square in the cardinal direction written in it. Since the page may be rotated, we test which side (A/B/C/D) must be true north so that some starting square produces a single path that visits all 9 squares.

If side **C** is north, then relative to the picture the moves become:
- N = move **down** (toward C)
- E = move **left**
- S = move **up**
- W = move **right**

Now start at the **center** square (it contains E). Following the directions gives:
center → left → down-left → down-middle → down-right → middle-right → top-right → top-middle → top-left → off the chart.
This passes over **all 9 squares exactly once** before exiting.

With north at A, B, or D, the forced path from any start either exits too soon or gets trapped in a small loop, so you cannot cover the whole chart.

We must use all five red tiles (1, 6, 2, +, =) together with the fixed green tiles 2 (at the start of the row) and 6 (near the end) to make an addition equation. Since only one “+” is available, the equation must be of the form A=B+C or A+B=C using exactly the digits 1,2,2,6,6. A valid sum that uses all those digits is 16+6=22. Rewriting it so the equation starts with the fixed leading 2 gives 22=16+6, and this also lets the fixed green 6 sit at the end (with the remaining slot left blank).

The symbols tell you the quantity by how many “connections” are made into the main vertical line on the right side of the symbol (ignore the small little tab sticking out to the right, which is the same on every chest).

- Chest A’s design only joins into that right-hand vertical once (the zigzag meets it at a single point) → 1 teddy bear.
- Chest C likewise has just one bar joining into the right-hand vertical → 1 teddy bear.
- Chest B has two separate bars joining into the right-hand vertical → 2 teddy bears.

Chest D’s symbol also has two separate bars joining into the right-hand vertical, so it must contain 2 teddy bears.

Each scoreboard starts at **58** and each person may change **only one square**, which means each final number must be obtainable from the shape of “58” by adding a single green square.

To get a difference of **39** from two numbers that are each only one-square away from 58, the natural target is:
- make one board a number in the **90s** (increase the tens digit from 5 to 9), and
- make the other board a number in the **50s** ending in **9** (increase the ones digit from 8 to 9).

And the board’s blocky digit style allows exactly those one-square upgrades:
- **5 → 9** by filling the missing square at the **upper-right** of the “5”. This turns **58 → 98**.
- **8 → 9** by filling the single square in the **lower inner gap** of the “8”, eliminating the lower “hole” so it reads as a **9**. This turns **58 → 59**.

These two results differ by **98 − 59 = 39**, and each required exactly one touched square.

answer: Order: A → E → B → D → C, so the culprit is A.
justification:
First note the two “small ones” are B and C (both short and squat). C says he was last to arrive, so C must be 5th.

A says “One of the small ones came third.” Since C is 5th, the only small one who can be 3rd is B. So B is 3rd.

E says there was already someone in front of him (so E is not 1st) and “A little one trailed behind me” (a small one directly after him). With B fixed as 3rd, the only way for a small one to be directly behind E is E = 2nd (so B can be right behind him).

D says the stained-robes shades were both in front of and behind him. The stained ones are E (blue) and C (red). Since C is 5th, D must be before C and also after E, placing D as 4th.

The only remaining position, 1st, is A. Therefore A entered first and is the culprit.

The six numbered “threads” are the main strands coming out of the web’s center. Any point on the outer web lies in a wedge (sector) between two of these main strands, and the spider’s simple rule is: start by taking either of the two main threads that border the sector containing the prey (both are equally direct ways to reach that spot by then moving along the cross-threads).

This matches the clues: A lies in the sector bordered by threads 2 and 5, so the spider can start on 2 or 5; B lies in the sector bordered by threads 1 and 2, so it can start on 1 or 2.

Looking at the diagram, C is in the top sector, bordered by threads 1 and 6. بنابراین the spider could start on either of those two threads to reach C.

The four photos show the same street corner at the same time of day, so the only way to order them is by things that change slowly over long periods.

Looking from picture to picture, several elements clearly “age” in one direction:
- The small poster/sign on the wall to the right of the doorway becomes progressively more damaged: in **C** it’s clean and intact, in **A** it’s starting to peel/dirty, in **B** it’s more worn, and in **D** it’s the most deteriorated.
- The general grime/rust on the large metal structure and the surrounding stonework also increases along that same sequence (cleanest in **C**, dirtiest in **D**).

Since these changes are cumulative (they don’t plausibly reverse between photos), the chronological order must run from the cleanest/most intact scene to the most worn-down one: **C → A → B → D**.

From the picture, B is clearly the biggest person, and A is the smallest.

1) A says, “I’m the smallest, but I’ll finish fourth!” so A is 4th.
2) “The second-fastest swimmer is standing next to the biggest person.” Since A (next to B) is 4th, A cannot be 2nd, so the other neighbor of B must be 2nd. That neighbor is C, so C is 2nd.
3) B says he’s not the fastest, so B isn’t 1st.
4) The “sweetest swimsuit” is the candy-striped suit (E). E says they’re “no match for big B,” meaning B finishes ahead of E. With places left {1st, 3rd, 5th} for B, D, E, B can’t be 1st and can’t be 5th (otherwise he couldn’t beat E), so B is 3rd and E is 5th.
5) That leaves D as the only remaining position: 1st. This also fits “I’ll beat the person beside me to win!” because D stands beside C/E and is faster than them.

Therefore, D is the fastest swimmer.

The tile face is a trapezoid: its two parallel edges are 12 inches and 10.5 inches, and the perpendicular distance between them is 10 inches.

To make a *square* (with straight sides), the “slanted” edge of the trapezoid can’t be left exposed—otherwise the outside boundary wouldn’t be straight. So tiles must be used in opposite-facing pairs so their slants cancel.

If you flip one tile and match it to another along the slanted side, the pair forms a perfect rectangle:
- rectangle height = 10 inches
- rectangle width = 12 + 10.5 = 22.5 inches

Now the problem becomes: what is the smallest square you can make from 22.5×10 rectangles?
The square’s side must be a common multiple of 22.5 and 10. The smallest is 90 inches:
- 90 ÷ 22.5 = 4 rectangles across
- 90 ÷ 10 = 9 rectangles down
So we need 4 × 9 = 36 such rectangles.

Each rectangle uses 2 tiles, so the fewest tiles needed is 36 × 2 = 72.

Treat the big cube as a 3×3×3 grid with coordinates:
- x = left→right,
- y = back→front,
- z = top→bottom.

Each picture is an “orthographic projection”:
- A (top view) tells which (x,y) columns contain at least one gem.
- B (side view) tells which (y,z) positions contain at least one gem (somewhere along x).
- C (front view) tells which (x,z) positions contain at least one gem (somewhere along y).

From A, gems can only be in the three (x,y) columns shown: (1,1), (2,1), and (1,2).

Now match B and C:
- In C, there are gems at (x,z) = (2,1) and (2,3). Since A shows x=2 only occurs at y=1, these must be at (2,1,1) and (2,1,3). (2 gems)
- In C, there are gems at (x,z) = (1,1) and (1,3). In B, the only depth that has z=1 and z=3 is y=1, so these must be at (1,1,1) and (1,1,3). (2 more gems; total 4)
- In B, there is a gem at (y,z) = (1,2). But C shows no gem at (x,z)=(2,2), so this (y=1,z=2) gem cannot be at x=2; it must be at x=1 → (1,1,2). (1 more; total 5)
- Finally, A and B both show a gem in the “(x,y)=(1,2)” column and at (y,z)=(2,2), forcing (1,2,2). (1 more; total 6)

All shown dots are accounted for, and every one of these six placements is forced (there’s no alternative location that wouldn’t create an extra dot in one of the views).

A mold works like a “negative”: the dessert takes the shape of the inside surface of the mold. When you remove it, you have to turn the mold over onto a plate, so you end up looking at the shape from the opposite side compared with the way the mold is shown.

That means the finished dessert will be the mirror image (left–right flipped) of the figure on the mold. In the mold picture, the large splayed foot (and the little curl on the head) are on the left; after turning it out, those features must appear on the right.

Among A–D, only **B** is the left–right mirror of the mold.

answer: Tap the bottom-right button (the button in the lower-right corner of the panel).
justification:
Each button sends you to exactly one next button (the one the arrow points to). If you start on the “wrong” button, you can never reach any button that doesn’t have an arrow leading into it from somewhere else, so you’d miss at least one button on the panel.

So the correct starting point must be the *only* button with **no incoming arrows** (no other button’s arrow points to it). Checking the panel, every button is pointed to by at least one neighbour’s arrow except the **bottom-right** one: the arrows in the rightmost column all point upward (so nothing points down into it), and the button to its left doesn’t point right into it either. That makes it the unique start that can lead through the entire chain of buttons.

To match the left picture, a candidate must reproduce the same line drawing once you (1) flip it left↔right and (2) invert its colours (so the blue areas become the light/white areas in the black‑and‑white negative).

Comparing A, B and C, only **A** has its major blue regions in exactly the two places that become the two strongest light patches in the black‑and‑white image after the left↔right flip (one near the top and one around the lower figure/object). The remaining tan/peach regions in A then correspond to the darker midtones in the negative, and the outline features (the position of the raised arm/hand and the vertical border blocks) line up after the flip. 

In B and C, at least one of these large blue areas is shifted to a different part of the drawing, so after flipping and inverting they would place a bright patch where the black‑and‑white image does not have one.

Look at the rows that the missing 2×3 section cuts through.

- In the top row of the hole, the symbols immediately to the left and right of the gap are both green X’s. In that row, the non‑X symbols repeat in the order **blue circle → orange diamond** between X’s, so the two missing symbols on that row must be **circle, then diamond**.

- In the middle row of the hole, the row you can see is alternating **orange diamond and green X** all the way across. Since the gap sits where two X’s should be, the two missing symbols there must both be **green X’s**.

- In the bottom row of the hole, the visible row follows the repeating sequence that places **orange diamond then red square** between the surrounding X’s at that position, so the bottom of the missing piece must be **diamond, then square**.

Putting these three required rows together gives:

Top: **circle – diamond**
Middle: **X – X**
Bottom: **diamond – square**

Among A–D, only **Option A** has exactly that 2×3 arrangement, so it’s the only piece that completes every row’s repeating pattern without breaking it at the edges of the gap.

The numbers are meant to be read like “calculator words.” If you turn the note upside down, the digits become letters (0→O, 1→I, 3→E, 4→H, 5→S, 7→L, 8→B), and you read each number in reverse order.

Reading from the bottom upward:
- 7718 → BILL
- 51 → IS
- 5508 → BOSS
- 34 → HE
- 57735 → SELLS
- 710 → OIL

So the hidden message is: “BILL IS BOSS. HE SELLS OIL.” That identifies the crime kingpin as Bill (not John or Todd).

One rider is towing a loaded trailer (with a passenger/weight in it) yet looks fairly relaxed and upright, while the other rider is hunched forward as if working hard. On a real incline, the uphill cyclist typically leans forward and strains, whereas the downhill cyclist can sit more comfortably even with extra load.

Since the cyclist moving to the right (toward B) is the relaxed one despite pulling the trailer, he must be going downhill. That means the opposite direction—toward A (left side)—is uphill.

Check each umbrella against the three requirements (blue handle, red rim, circular *rings* pattern):

- **A**: Blue handle and a red rim, but the canopy has no circular-ring pattern (it’s mostly plain/striped).
- **B**: Has a **red** handle, so it fails immediately.
- **C**: Has a blue handle and red rim, but the pattern is solid dots rather than circular **rings**.
- **D**: Has a **blue handle**, a **red rim**, and the canopy pattern is made of circular **rings**.

So only **D** satisfies all conditions.

answer: Press the panel near the right side that contains the small round watch/clock face at the top (the second panel from the right).
justification:
The big grandfather clock image (numbers and pendulum) is spread across several door panels, so multiple panels could be said to be “with the clock,” which would make the instruction impossible if taken that way.

The trick is to look for a *complete timepiece contained within a single panel*. One panel has a small, round watch/clock face (a pocket‑watch-like timepiece) drawn entirely inside it, unlike the large clock that’s split by the panel dividers. That’s the only unambiguous “panel with the timepiece.”

Because the paint is opaque, whatever is painted on the upper sheets is what you will see in that square; anything on a lower sheet only matters where the sheets above it are clear.

Look at the squares that must end up as the *light* squares of the final checkerboard. Several of those squares are painted on sheet **A** (it has a large connected block of painted squares). If **A** were placed above another sheet, those adjacent painted squares would remain visible and you could not get an alternating pattern there.

However, those same “should-be-light” squares are provided as light squares by sheet **B** (and can therefore cover A’s paint if B is above A). So A’s painted areas that would otherwise break the checkerboard have to be *covered* from above—meaning **A must be underneath the other sheets**.

So the only way to allow the correct alternating pattern to appear is to put **A** on the very bottom, letting B (and the remaining sheet) sit above it and overwrite the squares where A would ruin the checkerboard.

To fit, the screw’s thread has to match the hole in two ways: (1) the *handedness* (right‑hand vs left‑hand), and (2) the *pitch* (spacing between thread ridges). The hole’s thread, as drawn, spirals in the normal tightening direction (the green arrow shows the direction to turn to drive it in), and its grooves are relatively fine/closely spaced. Comparing the six screws, A and C have a noticeably coarser pitch, and B and E have the opposite (left‑hand) thread direction. F’s pitch doesn’t match the hole’s groove spacing. Only **D** has the same tightening direction *and* the same fine thread spacing as the hole, so it’s the only one that will engage smoothly and fit properly.

The shapes alternate as “square → inscribed circle → inscribed square → inscribed circle → inscribed (red) square”.

Let the blue square have side length S.
- The circle inside it has diameter S.
- A square inscribed in that circle has diagonal S, so its side is S/√2.
- The next circle is inscribed in that square, so its diameter is S/√2.
- The red square is inscribed in this circle, so its diagonal is S/√2, giving red side (S/√2)/√2 = S/2.

So areas: blue = S², red = (S/2)² = S²/4. Therefore the blue square’s area is 4 times the red square’s area.

The trick is that you’re not meant to estimate the real anatomical bone count of the species (which could indeed be in the hundreds), but to count the individual bone pieces that are actually drawn in the displayed skeleton.

If you carefully tally each separate bone shape in the picture (counting each vertebra segment, each rib shown, the skull and jaw as separate pieces, and the limb segments as separate pieces), the total comes to 58 bones in this exhibit.

The “secret number” isn’t in the teeth of the keys at all, but in their heads: each key has a round hole. With the keys shown one above the other, those two holes line up like two stacked circles, which is exactly the shape of the digit **8**. That’s the number hidden “in” the keys.

The hint means to use buoyancy: if you drop the balls into the glass tank, the wooden balls will float and the metal balls will sink. So the lock code must be made from the number panels attached to the *wooden* balls (the ones the water will “answer” with by floating).

From the picture, trace each string from a wooden ball to its panel:
- The wooden ball on the far left is tied to the panel marked **9**.
- The wooden ball near the bottom/centre-left is tied to the panel marked **8**.
- The wooden ball on the upper right is tied to the panel marked **4**.

When these float, you read them in their left-to-right order to form the code.

The matchsticks read as Roman numerals: **I + XI = X** (1 + 11 = 10), which is false. The quickest fix is to change **XI (11)** into **IX (9)** by moving the single matchstick that forms the **I** in “XI” from the right side of that X to the left side of it. Then the equation becomes **I + IX = X**, i.e., **1 + 9 = 10**, which is a valid Roman-numeral equation. Only one matchstick needs to be moved.

answer: The next attack will occur on the same square as attack 15 (second row, far-right square).
justification:
Number the 16 squares in reading order (left→right, top→bottom) as positions 1–16.

Now convert each attack’s location into this position number:
1→1, 2→3, 3→6, 4→10, 5→15, 6→5, 7→12, 8→4, 9→13, 10→7, 11→2, 12→14, 13→11, 14→9, 15→8.

Look at the jump sizes (wrapping around after 16):
1→3 is +2, 3→6 is +3, 6→10 is +4, …, and 9→8 is +15.
So each time, the machine advances by 2 squares, then 3, then 4, and so on—always increasing the step by 1.

Therefore the next step after attack 15 must be +16 squares, which on a 16-square grid brings you back to the same square. Attack 15 is on position 8 (row 2, column 4), so attack 16 lands there again.

answer: Equal — section II has the same area as section I (I = II).
justification:
The “marble” boundary is made by using the three equal parts of the diameter as the size of the three circular “drops” (each part gives the same diameter, so each drop-circle has the same area). In this kind of marbling construction, when a new circle is added it does not change the *total* amount of any previous color: it only pushes portions of earlier colors aside. Concretely, whatever area of an earlier color is covered by the new circle is exactly replaced by an equal area of that earlier color pushed outward, so the net area of each color stays equal to the area of its original drop-circle.

Since all three drops are the same size (because the diameter was trisected), the three colored sections must all have the same area. We’re told I and III match; the same reasoning forces II to match them as well.

The “changing toppings” are being used to *show the time* like a clock face.

- Around the edge of the pizza, the toppings are placed at 12 evenly spaced positions, like the hour marks on an analog clock.
- In the middle, the thin rectangular toppings form two clear “hands.”
- One hand points straight up to the 12 o’clock position, which means the minutes are :00 (the riddle also tells us it was ordered exactly on the hour).
- The other (shorter) hand points down-left to the 7 o’clock position.

So the pizza is showing 7:00 after noon.

To show every date from 01 to 31 using two dice, some digits must appear on *both* dice. In particular, you must be able to make 10, 20, and 30, which all require a 0 in the ones place while the other die shows 1, 2, or 3 in the tens place. That’s impossible unless **both dice have a 0**.

In the layouts shown, only one die has a 0, so dates like **10** can’t be displayed.

Since we’re allowed to change only one face, we should replace a digit we can still “get” another way. A **9** is already present on the other die, and a 9 can be turned upside down to serve as a **6**. Therefore the best single change is to replace the **6** with **0**, giving 0 on both dice without losing the ability to show 6.

Model the cube as a graph: corners are vertices and wire lengths are edges. The ant may revisit corners, but it may not traverse any wire length twice, so we need an Euler trail.

Because the cube is sitting on the floor, the ant can always drop down to the floor at any bottom corner and walk on the floor to any other bottom corner without using any wire. In graph terms, the four bottom corners behave like a single “super-vertex” (the floor lets you move among them freely). That super-vertex ends up having an even total degree, so it causes no problem.

The only problematic vertices are the four top corners: each has 3 incident wire lengths (odd degree). So we effectively have 4 odd-degree vertices. To make an Euler trail possible, we must reduce this to exactly 2 odd-degree vertices. Adding one wire flips the parity of exactly the two vertices it connects, so the only way is to connect two of the odd top corners together.

Placing the added wire in area A (the top face) allows exactly that: it connects two top corners, making those two corners even-degree and leaving only two odd corners overall (the start corner and the remaining top corner). Then an Euler trail exists starting at the ant.

In contrast, adding the wire in area B (top-to-bottom) would make the bottom “super-vertex” odd, and adding it in area C (bottom face) doesn’t reduce the number of odd top corners—so neither B nor C works.

When you pull the two ends of the red rope, the only part that actually “locks” is the red rope’s own crossing in the middle: that crossing tightens into an overhand knot, and anything that is threaded through the *loop of red rope that collapses into the knot* becomes trapped.

Looking at the tangle, two of the colored loops (the green loop and the blue loop) pass through that would‑be red loop on opposite sides of the red crossing. So, as the red rope cinches down, they are pulled into the tightening turns of the knot and end up genuinely linked to the knot (you can’t tug them out without loosening the red knot).

The remaining loop (the orange/yellow one) is only “laid across” the red rope/other loops: it doesn’t actually pass through the collapsing red loop that forms the knot. So even if it looks like it gets dragged inward, it can still be pulled free with a tug and shouldn’t be counted.

The garden area is a 6×4 grid (24 squares) with 4 flower bushes that must be left uncovered, so exactly 20 squares need paving. That means you must be able to cover the remaining space with 4 identical stones of 5 squares each.

Because of where the 4 bushes sit, the usable area naturally splits into four separate 3×2 rectangles, each with the “middle square on one side” removed by a bush. So in each 3×2 section you need a stone that covers exactly 5 of those 6 squares.

Among A–E, only stone **C** (the U-shaped pentomino) is exactly “a 3×2 rectangle missing the middle square on one edge.” By rotating C appropriately in each of the four 3×2 sections, it fills all paving squares while leaving each bush square empty, with no overlaps.

The other stones don’t match this forced 3×2-minus-1 structure (and the long bar B can’t be arranged to avoid the interior bushes), so they cannot tile the space cleanly.

Each pebble creates its own set of concentric circular ripples, so the number of pebbles equals the number of distinct ripple “centres.”

In the photo, two centres are obvious because you can see complete bull’s-eyes:
1) one in the lower-left, and
2) one in the upper-right.

The remaining white curves are not all concentric with either of those two. If you mentally continue the arcs into full circles, you can group them into three additional families of concentric circles whose centres lie outside the photographed rectangle:
- one set curves as if centred off the left edge,
- one set curves as if centred above the top edge,
- one set curves as if centred below the bottom edge.

That gives 2 visible centres + 3 off-screen centres = 5 pebbles total.

answer: Pull up (mark) the middle-right post next to the man, and the lower-middle post.
justification:
To see which posts matter, ignore the loose-looking coils and instead follow the “linking” of rope and post.

- If a post is only touched by an open bend of rope, then when the man runs and the rope is pulled tight, that bend can simply slide along the rope and disappear (the rope is not truly hooked on the post).
- A post *does* stop him only when the rope forms a closed, tightening loop around it (a locked loop created by the rope crossing back through itself). In that case, pulling the rope only cinches the loop against the post, so the rope cannot slide free unless the post is removed.

In the picture, only two posts are inside such locked loops:
1) the post immediately to the man’s right (middle-right post), and
2) the post in the lower middle of the scene.

All other posts are only bordered by slack/open loops that will pull straight and slip off when he runs.

answer: Circle the spot on the upper-left side: the position directly above the red dot (its mirror across the horizontal center line of the shape).
justification:
Flipping a flat shape over while keeping your fingers in the same places is a 180° turn around the line joining your fingers (the “hinge” axis). Anything printed on the reverse side will therefore appear as a mirror image across that hinge line.

Diagram A shows exactly this mirroring: when the shape is held top–bottom and flipped, the dot ends up at the left–right mirrored position.

In Diagram B, the shape is being held left–right instead, so the hinge line runs horizontally through the shape. That means the dot’s position will be mirrored top-to-bottom (but stay the same left-to-right).

So the black dot must appear directly opposite the red dot across the horizontal midline of the shape—same left/right position, but the corresponding spot above the center.

The cut shown divides the triangular cake into a smaller triangle (labeled 4) and the remaining larger piece (labeled 5). For that to happen with a single straight cut across the cake’s two sides, the cut must be **parallel to the third side**, making the small top piece a **similar triangle** to the whole cake.

Let the whole (equilateral) triangle have side 15 in, and let the small similar triangle have side length x (measured from the top vertex down to where the cut meets each side).

The area ratio is 4:5, so the small triangle’s area is
\[\frac{4}{4+5}=\frac{4}{9}\]
of the total area.

For similar triangles, area scales as the square of the side scale factor:
\[\left(\frac{x}{15}\right)^2 = \frac{4}{9}\]
\[\frac{x}{15} = \frac{2}{3}\]
\[x = 15\cdot \frac{2}{3} = 10\]

So he should make the cut where it hits each side **10 inches from the vertex** (equivalently 5 inches up from the base).

From the picture, the four-card sequences (top→bottom) are:
- A: Water, Wood, Water, Fire
- B: Water, Fire, Water, Fire
- C: Wood, Water, Wood, Water
- D: Water, Wood, Fire, Fire
Rule: Fire > Wood > Water > Fire.

Actual tournament:
1) A vs B: Water vs Water is a draw, so discard and continue. Next is Wood (A) vs Fire (B), so B wins and advances.
2) C vs D: Wood (C) vs Water (D) → Wood wins, so C advances.
Final (using remaining cards):
- B has Water, Fire left; C has Water, Wood, Water left.
Water vs Water draws; then Fire (B) vs Wood (C) → Fire wins, so B is champion.

Now check who could truthfully say “I’d have won if wood and water were swapped” (i.e., all their Woods become Waters and all their Waters become Woods, keeping order).
Only for C: C would become Water, Wood, Water, Wood. Then in the semi vs D, the first two rounds draw (Water/Water, Wood/Wood), and then Water beats D’s Fire, so C advances with a final Wood remaining. In the final, B’s next card is Water, and C’s is Wood, so Wood beats Water immediately and C becomes champion.
No other player becomes champion under that personal swap.

Therefore, the speaker must be player C.

answer:
Take the caves in this order:

**1→2: lower cave**, **2→3: lower cave**, **3→4: upper cave**, **4→5: upper cave**.

(Photos in order: **C, D, A, B**.)
justification:
First match each photo to the *area it is looking out onto* (the light part of each picture):

- **B** shows a green field full of **flowers** → that can only be **area 5**.
- **A** shows mostly **sand/rocky yellow ground** with just a little grass → that matches the sandy **area 4**.
- Of the two remaining, **D** is the only one where you can see **other cave mouths in the distance**. The only place on the map where you emerge into a grassy area and can look straight across to a wall with multiple exits is the central grassy hub, **area 3** (you can see the two exits on the far wall).
- Therefore **C** must be the remaining grassy area, **area 2**.

So the successful explorer’s photos must be in travel order:
**1→2: C**, **2→3: D**, **3→4: A**, **4→5: B**.

Now choose which of the two caves to use at each step:
- **1→2 (photo C):** the view is straight onto a plain cliff/grass scene, not directly onto the next set of cave mouths, which corresponds to entering area 2 via the **lower** of the two 1–2 caves.
- **2→3 (photo D):** you can clearly see both exits on the far wall in area 3; that full view happens when you enter area 3 from the **lower** 2–3 cave (the higher one doesn’t give as clear a line of sight to both).
- **3→4 (photo A):** you can see a strip of greenery above the sandy ground, consistent with entering the sandy area high up → take the **upper** 3–4 cave.
- **4→5 (photo B):** you look out over the flower field from a higher position → take the **upper** 4–5 cave.

That yields one consistent safe chain of exactly four caves from 1 to 5.

Reading the maze, the centre (start) square contains a **2**, so every move from there must be exactly 2 squares.

A route to **B** exists:
1) Start (centre) **2** → move **right 2** to a **2**.
2) From that **2** → move **right 2** to the right-edge square **3**.
3) From **3** → move **left 3** to a **2**.
4) From **2** → move **right 2** to a **2** (this is two squares left of the goal).
5) From this **2** → move **right 2** and you land exactly on goal **B** (jumping over the edge square).

The other goals can’t be landed on exactly:
- To reach **A** (top goal) you must be somewhere in A’s column with a number equal to the exact remaining distance to the top goal; in that column, none of the numbers match the needed distances.
- Similarly, **C** (bottom goal) would require an exact-distance number in C’s column; none match.
- To reach **D** (left goal) you’d need, on D’s row, a square whose number equals its exact horizontal distance to the left goal; no square on that row has the required value.

Therefore only **B** is reachable.

For the remaining five rings to form a single long chain, each ring must be linked to at most two others (the two end rings link to only one).

Looking at the over/under weaving in the picture, ring **B** is the “extra” connector: it threads through the middle and links into the cluster on both sides, creating a loop/branch rather than a simple path. If you cut away **B**, the remaining links fall into a clean end‑to‑end order:

**A** is linked only to **D**, **D** to **E**, **E** to **C**, and **C** to **F** — giving the single chain

**A – D – E – C – F**.

Cutting any other ring either leaves a branching point (a ring still linked to three others) or splits the set into separate groups, so only **B** produces one long 5‑ring chain.

answer: The knight on the left (mid-left) owns the strange curved sword.
justification:
Looking at the blades sticking out of the meat, all of them are straight except the long one jutting out to the right, which is slightly bowed/curved.

Since the knights all stabbed their swords all the way into (and through) the meat, the blade that’s visible on one side must belong to the knight holding the hilt on the opposite side. The curved blade sticks out on the right, so its hilt must be on the left side of the meat.

The only knight thrusting a sword into the meat from the left side (at the same height as that right-pointing blade) is the left-side knight, so he must be the owner of the oddly curved sword.

Because one picture is just a left-right mirror and a rotation of the other, you can pick an obvious reference (for example the orange crescent) and mentally flip one circle left-right, then rotate it until the crescent and the central white burst line up.

Once aligned, every symbol matches its partner (the squares, the wavy lines, and the letters all end up in the same relative positions and orientations after the flip/rotation) except for the star in the lower-right sector of the right-hand circle. That star’s outline/points don’t match the corresponding star in the other circle (it has a different point structure), meaning it is the one symbol that was altered rather than merely moved by the flip+spin.

So the different shape is the star at position D.

From the picture, the books are piled as 3 stacks across and 3 stacks back (a 3×3 set of piles), so there are 9 separate piles on the table.

Each librarian is looking from a different side. In each line of sight, shorter piles are completely hidden behind the tallest pile in that line, so what each librarian reports is the *maximum height* in each of the three lines.

- The first librarian’s view shows three visible pile-heights: **4, 2, 3**. So the maxima for the three lines they look across are 4, 2, and 3.
- The second librarian’s view shows three visible pile-heights: **2, 4, 3**. So the maxima for the three perpendicular lines are 2, 4, and 3.

Now fill the 3×3 grid with the smallest possible number of books while still achieving those row/column maxima (any extra books would be hidden and would increase the total).
- A line with maximum **4** and the perpendicular line with maximum **4** must share a pile of height **4**.
- Similarly, a **3**-maximum line and a **3**-maximum perpendicular line must share a pile of height **3**.
- A **2**-maximum line and a **2**-maximum perpendicular line must share a pile of height **2**.
- All other piles can be just **1** book high (they must exist, but must not raise any maximum).

So the total is:
- one pile of 4
- one pile of 3
- one pile of 2
- the remaining 6 piles are 1 each

Total = 4 + 3 + 2 + 6×1 = **15** books.

answer: The baseball glove/mitt (it’s the wrong-handed glove for the athlete).
justification:
All the balls and the bat can be used regardless of whether the athlete is left- or right-handed. The only item here that’s inherently “handed” is the baseball glove/mitt: it’s made to be worn on one specific hand (you can tell by where the thumb section is). If the athlete’s dominant/throwing hand is the opposite of what that glove is designed for, then using it would put them at a disadvantage and they couldn’t play at their absolute best.

So the comment is pointing to the glove being for the wrong hand.

The instruction is a wordplay on how the numbers sound. “Two” sounds like **to**, and “four” sounds like **for**. So the sentence can be read as: **Open with ‘to’, but leave ‘for’.** Converting those homophones back into digits gives **2** (to) followed by **4** (for). That’s why pressing only 2 doesn’t work, and why 4 must also be used.

answer: Circle the **last letter (the final N)**—it’s drawn backwards.
justification: The word is supposed to read **LONDON** (L‑O‑N‑D‑O‑N). The easiest way to spot the mistake is to compare the two **N**’s: the first N (3rd letter) is drawn normally with its diagonal slanting one way, but the last “N” (6th letter) has the diagonal slanting the opposite way, meaning it’s a **mirror image/backwards N** (it looks like the Cyrillic letter **И**). Since only one letter differs from the correct spelling, that backwards final N is the single incorrect letter.

Treat the colour code at the top as the repeating order of squares you must step on: starting on the centre red square, your next square must be blue, then yellow, then red, etc., moving only to an adjacent square and never reusing a square.

From the centre red square the only workable blue move is to the right (going down leads to a dead end under the no-reuse rule). From there the forced sequence is:

Red (start) → Blue (right) → Yellow (right) → Red (right edge) → Blue (up) → Yellow (left) → Red (up) → Blue (right) → Yellow (up).

That final yellow square is the top-right corner of the grid, labelled **B**, so that is the corner button that unlocks the door.

The red arrow shows the starting point and the direction you’re facing (along the bottom road, heading to the right).

1) Go straight until you reach the first place you can turn left: that happens at the junction at **G**, where a road goes upward. Turn left there (so you go up toward the middle of the map).
2) Continue to the next junction at **E**. From that direction, the next instructed turn is a **right**, which takes you onto the road going to the right-hand side of the village.
3) At the next junction on the right-hand side (the crossroads on the vertical road that leads up toward C), take the next **left**, which turns you upward.

After that last left, going straight puts **C** directly in front of you, so that is where the clock tower is.

The clue says the village is on a road that doesn’t take you to any *other* town. On the map, most villages sit on the connected road network in the middle/right, so from them you can drive along the road and eventually reach other villages.

The only exception is the village at the top-left: it sits on its own circular road. The point where that loop seems to meet the rest of the roads is actually just a crossing/overpass (the roads pass over/under each other), so there’s no junction connecting it to the other routes. If you travel its road, you only go around the same loop and never reach another town.

Therefore, the correct village is the isolated one in the top-left.

The three “took turns” photos should have been taken within minutes of each other, so the background conditions (especially the sky) should match.

In photos **A, C, and D**, the clouds form the same pattern/placement behind the viewpoint and the distant buildings are lit in the same way, indicating the same moment/day.

Photo **B** has a noticeably different sky (clouds/lighting don’t match the other three), so it must be the one taken on a different day.

Therefore, the tourists who traveled together took **A, C, and D**.

Both the lamppost and the 1 m post are lit by the same light source, so the triangles formed by their heights and their shadows are similar. That means the ratio height ÷ shadow length is the same for both.

For the 1 m post: 1 ÷ 1.5 = 2/3.

The lamppost’s shadow is marked as 3 m long, so its height is:
(2/3) × 3 = 2 m.

So the lamppost must be 2 meters tall.

Each flower in a given bunch has the same number of petals (shown under A–D). Since he’ll play one “petal game” per flower, the florist wants a petal count that makes the *last* petal land on the best outcome in all three games.

1) **“She loves me / she loves me not”** alternates every petal, starting with “She loves me.”
- Odd petals → ends on **“She loves me.”**

2) **“Happy / unhappy / so-so”** repeats every 3 petals, starting with “Happy.”
- Petals ≡ 1 (mod 3) → ends on **“Happy.”**

3) **“A bouquet / a cake / a ring / a book”** repeats every 4 petals, starting with “A bouquet.”
- Petals ≡ 3 (mod 4) → ends on **“a ring”** (the best choice).

Now test the options:
- A: 11 is odd, but 11 ≡ 2 (mod 3) → ends on “unhappy.”
- **B: 7 is odd; 7 ≡ 1 (mod 3) → “Happy”; and 7 ≡ 3 (mod 4) → “a ring.”**
- C: 16 is even → ends on “She loves me not.”
- D: 13 is odd and 13 ≡ 1 (mod 3) → “Happy,” but 13 ≡ 1 (mod 4) → “a bouquet,” not the best final outcome.

So only bunch **B** gives the best result in all three games.

In a real London phone box, only one side is a door; that door has a handle. In the photo, booths A, B and D each show a door handle, meaning you can open them and use the phone inside. Booth C is the only one with no handle at all, so we’re looking at its back (a fixed panel), not an opening door. Since the boxes are lined up against the wall behind them, that means booth C’s door must be facing the wall and can’t be opened/entered from the street—so it can’t be used.

Call the three flags in the example (from left to right) A = green-over-white, B = purple checkered, C = blue–orange–blue striped. We only count cases where these three appear consecutively on the *same* string in that exact order (not reversed, and not broken up by crossing strings).

Scanning each rope of flags in the picture and checking every run of three adjacent flags, the pattern A→B→C occurs twice: once on the upper string (green/white, then purple-check, then blue/orange), and once again on another string where the same three flags appear consecutively in the same order. No other purple-check flag has a green/white immediately on its left *and* a blue/orange immediately on its right.

So the shown 3-flag sequence appears 2 times.

The pattern on the flag is a 5×5 chequered grid (you can tell because the light squares form the alternating 3-2-3-2-3 layout, which only happens on a 5-wide checkerboard). 

When a riddle asks for “how many squares are on the flag”, it’s counting squares of every possible size in that grid, not just the 1×1 ones:
- 1×1 squares: 5×5 = 25
- 2×2 squares: 4×4 = 16
- 3×3 squares: 3×3 = 9
- 4×4 squares: 2×2 = 4
- 5×5 squares: 1×1 = 1
Total on one side: 25+16+9+4+1 = 55.

The statement that the flag has the same design on its front and back matters: it means those 55 squares appear on both sides, so we count them twice.

55×2 = 110.

answer: The lone item is the blue ball (the single blue sphere in the center).
justification: Looking over the dropped props, every kind of item appears twice: there are two orange balls, two purple balls, matching rings/hoops, and matching box-shaped props. Only one ball is different—there’s a single blue ball in the middle with no second blue ball anywhere in the pile. That makes it the only item missing its partner.

Because the shelf is completely packed and every encyclopedia has the same depth (the shelf is exactly that deep), you can’t push neighboring books backward to make room. That means the first book you remove must be one whose spine is already accessible from the front.

In the picture, book 7 sits farther back than both books next to it (6 and 8), whose spines protrude farther forward. With the row packed tight, book 7 is effectively “shielded” by those two books: you can’t get a grip on it or slide it straight out until you first remove one of its neighbors.

So regardless of what someone is looking up, book 7 can’t be the first book taken from the shelf.

The mathematician’s long product is essentially

(x−a)(x−b)(x−c)⋯(x−z),

i.e., one factor (x−letter) for every letter of the alphabet.
Since **x** itself is one of the letters in the alphabet, one of the factors must be **(x−x)**.
But (x−x)=0, and any product containing a zero factor is 0, regardless of what numbers are substituted for any of the letters.
So the whole expression is always the same value.

Each lower number is formed by adding together the sums of the digits of the two adjacent numbers above it.

Check the top row:
- From 160 and 144: (1+6+0)=7 and (1+4+4)=9; 7+9=16.
- From 144 and 162: (1+4+4)=9 and (1+6+2)=9; 9+9=18.
- From 162 and 687: (1+6+2)=9 and (6+8+7)=21; 9+21=30.

This rule also fits the lower row:
- From 18 and 30: (1+8)=9 and (3+0)=3; 9+3=12.
- Bottom check: if the missing number is 16, then from 16 and 12: (1+6)=7 and (1+2)=3; 7+3=10, matching the bottom.

So the missing number must be 16.

Because the pond is undercut, the rim of the net can run under the bank and “disappear” from the surface view. However, we’re told the rim is one single rope with its two ends on the shore (in your hands), so all the visible “loose-looking” rim segments must actually connect up into one continuous boundary.

If you trace that boundary consistently as one rope, it forms a single enclosed region (completed by the short stretch of shoreline between your hands). A fish will be snared exactly if you cannot reach the outside/shore from it without crossing the rim (i.e., it lies inside that closed boundary). Counting the fish that lie in this enclosed region gives 8; the rest have a clear path to the outside without crossing the rim and won’t be trapped when the net is lifted.

If a cube is cut into two congruent halves, the second half is the **mirror image** of the first across the cut surface. Therefore, for “two identical copies” of one half to make the cube, that half must be **superimposable on its own mirror image** (i.e., it must be achiral / not “left- or right-handed”).

Pieces **A**, **B**, and **D** each have a symmetry/arrangement that makes them effectively the same as their mirror after a rotation, so two identical copies can be oriented to play the roles of the two cube halves.

Piece **C** is a *handed* (chiral) step/L-shaped form: its mirror would have the “step” on the opposite side. Since you can’t obtain that mirror version by rotating an identical copy of C, two C pieces can’t form a perfect cube when joined (you’d need one left-handed and one right-handed version).

The girl says her mother has **red hair** and owns a **pink purse with a bear on it**.

In the picture, the **pink bear purse is the one woman B is holding**, but B immediately says: **“Hold on. This isn’t my purse!”** So B is not the owner of the pink bear purse.

Now eliminate the others:
- **C** can’t be the mother because C says **“I’m actually a man.”**
- **D** can’t be the owner of the pink bear purse because D says **her purse is blue**.
- **E** also says the bag being held **isn’t hers** (wrong pattern), so E isn’t the owner of the bear purse either.

That leaves **A** as the only remaining red‑haired woman who could own the **pink bear purse** (even though it’s currently in B’s hands). Therefore, **A is the girl’s mother**.

When you pull the two ends, the rope straightens, but the coins can’t pass through the rope. That means each coin stays on the same *side* of the rope throughout the tightening (it just gets pushed along as the rope moves).

So the question becomes: which coins are on the same side of the rope as the “top side” of the final straight rope?
A reliable way to determine that from the tangled picture is:
- For each coin, draw an imaginary straight line from the coin to the top edge of the screen.
- Count how many times that line crosses the rope.
- If it crosses the rope an **even** number of times (including zero), the coin is on the **top side**; if **odd**, it’s on the bottom side.

Doing this for all the coins in the picture shows that **9** of them have an even number of crossings, so those 9 end up on the top half when the rope is pulled taut.

Even though none of the buildings has a written sign saying “HOTEL,” one of them still carries a typical hotel mark: a single “H” displayed on the front.

If you look closely at building **C**, there’s a round plaque/emblem on its facade (between the middle-floor windows) that shows an **H**, which is a common way to indicate a hotel without spelling the word out. The other buildings don’t have that identifying hotel symbol.

Therefore, **C** is the hotel.

answer: Circle the area underneath the train car (the lower part of the carriage), where the wheels/bogies should be—because the train has no wheels and appears to be floating.
justification: A train can’t be standing at a platform without wheels/undercarriage visible. In the picture, the passenger car’s side continues down to a flat bottom edge, but there are no wheels (or bogies) anywhere beneath it—making it look like the car is floating above the track area. That’s the single physically unrealistic detail in the scene.

answer: Seat 2 (the middle seat on the left side of the table).
justification:
From the picture the table has 5 seats on each long side. The husbands are already known and fixed: right side (top→bottom) A, (seat 4), B, (seat 5), C; left side (top→bottom) (seat 1), D, (seat 2), E, (seat 3). The numbered positions 1–5 are the only empty seats (the wives’ seats).

Use the rules “no one sits opposite their spouse” and “no one sits next to their spouse” to list possible wife-seats for each husband:
- A (top-right) can only have his wife at seat 2, seat 3, or seat 5.
- B (middle-right) can only have his wife at seat 1 or seat 3.
- C (bottom-right) can only have his wife at seat 1, seat 2, or seat 4.
- D (upper-left-middle) can only have his wife at seat 3 or seat 5.
- E (lower-left-middle) can only have his wife at seat 1 or seat 4.

Now apply “Wife A and wife B sit on opposite sides of the table” (one must be on the left, the other on the right). If E’s wife were on the left (seat 1), then B’s wife is forced to seat 3 (also left), and A’s wife is forced to seat 2 (left), making wives A and B on the same side—impossible. Therefore E’s wife must be on the right (seat 4).

With seat 4 taken, C can’t use seat 4 and can’t use seat 5 (next to C), so the only consistent overall assignment forces C’s wife into seat 2 (the only remaining seat that allows everyone else to be seated without breaking the rules, while also keeping wives A and B on opposite sides).

Therefore wife C’s seat is number 2.

The arrow at the top marks the opening back to the surface. If you trace each tunnel without switching at crossings, only one of the three entrances connects to that opening.

- Tunnel **C** winds through the lower passages and ends at the creature/bone area on the lower right (a dead end).
- Tunnel **A** stays in the upper-left network and loops around without ever reaching the surface opening.
- Tunnel **B** is the only path that continues through the central passages and reaches the top opening under the arrow.

So the bird must choose the tunnel that actually connects to the surface exit.

If you scan the painting for silhouettes that have the key “cat markers” (pointed ears, head/shoulder curve, a long tail, and the typical sitting/arching body outline), you can pick out nine distinct cat shapes blended into the brushstrokes and background.

They aren’t all drawn as full cats in the same style: some are clear white/solid shapes (the large central one), while others are formed by negative space or by the darker, angular strokes around the oval and in the brown area to the right. Counting each separate complete cat silhouette once (even if only the outline is suggested) gives a total of 9 hidden cats.

answer: The spot directly underneath his recliner (the floor under where he’s sitting).
justification: All of his gadgets (rod, extendo-arm, magnets) can be aimed around the room to grab things at a distance. The only area they *can’t* reach is the space physically blocked by his own body and the recliner itself—there’s no way to touch that spot while he stays seated, because the chair is sitting on it. To reach it, he’d have to stand up and move the recliner.

answer: Circle the middle window on the sun-facing (right) side of the building—the window next to the teacup and above the red flag.
justification: The doctor says he can watch the sunrise, so his window must be on the side of the building that faces the sun (the right-hand wall in the picture, where the sun is drawn). He also mentions seeing a flag “outside my window” and taking a sip of tea—so we should pick the sun-facing window that has the flag right outside it and the teacup detail at/near it. Finally, the “music drifting from a nearby window” fits because this window is right by the corner, close enough to the neighboring window around the corner for sound to carry. The only window that matches all these details is the middle window on the right-hand wall (the one by the teacup and the red flag).

A wax seal works like a normal stamp: whatever you see in the wax is the *mirror image* of what’s carved on the stamp face. Luke’s used seal shows a normal-looking “L” (the long stroke on the left with the base curling to the right), so the real stamp must have the “L” carved backwards (long stroke on the right, base curling left). Among A–D, only **B** shows the correctly mirrored (backwards) “L” shape that would produce the seal shown.

The survey is asking where, at any given time throughout the year, you’d find the greatest number of injured people and people who have died. Regardless of where accidents or crimes actually happen (crossroads, park, etc.), the injured are taken to the hospital for treatment, and many deaths are also recorded there. So the one place that consistently has the highest average of injured people and deaths is the hospital.

Model the burrow as a graph: each tunnel is an edge, and every hole/junction where tunnels meet is a vertex. The mole wants to travel every tunnel exactly once, which is an Euler trail problem.

An Euler trail is possible only when the graph has exactly 0 or 2 vertices of odd degree (odd number of tunnels meeting there). If there are 2 odd-degree vertices, the trail must start at one odd vertex and end at the other.

Counting the number of tunnels at each point in the picture:
- Hole **A** is a dead end (only **1** tunnel connects to it) → odd degree.
- All the other labeled holes (B–G) have an even number of connecting tunnels (2 or 4) → even degree.
- There is exactly one *unlabeled* junction immediately to the right of A where **3** tunnels meet → the only other odd-degree vertex.

So the burrow has exactly two odd-degree vertices: hole **A** and that nearby 3-way junction. Therefore the only way to traverse every tunnel once is to start at **A** (and the route will finish at that 3-way junction).

This is a map-colouring problem: two sections only “touch” if they share a boundary segment (touching at a point doesn’t count).

In the middle of the drawing you can pick out three sections that form a closed loop where each one shares an edge with the other two (a 3-cycle/“triangle” of mutually adjacent regions). There is also a central section that shares an edge with all three of those surrounding sections.

Those four sections therefore form the standard 4-region configuration (equivalent to K4 in the adjacency graph): the three surrounding regions must already use 3 different colours because they all touch each other, and the central region can’t use any of those 3 because it touches all three—so a 4th colour is forced.

Since any planar subdivision can be coloured with 4 colours and this one actually forces 4, the fewest possible is 4.

answer: Use 3 stamps: 2, 3, and 7. Fill the squares as: 2 + 2 + 3 = 7.
justification:
The equation is of the form □ + □ + □ = □, using the available digit stamps {8, 4, 2, 3, 7}, and you may reuse a chosen stamp multiple times.

- Using 1 stamp (one digit x) would force x + x + x = x ⇒ 3x = x ⇒ x = 0, but 0 isn’t available.
- Using 2 different stamps (digits x < y) the only way three digits can add to a single digit already in {x,y} is x + x + x = y (since any sum involving y is already ≥ y + x > y). That requires y = 3x, but none of the available pairs satisfy this (e.g., 3·2=6 not available).

So at least 3 different stamps are necessary. With 3 stamps it’s possible, for example:
2 + 2 + 3 = 7, which uses only the stamps 2, 3, and 7 and fills all four squares.

Notice that the animal pictures aren’t standing for fixed numbers; they’re standing for the *parity of each decimal digit* in the answer.

Check the given truths:
- 0+1 = 1, and the digit 1 is **odd** → shown as a **dog**.
- 6+3 = 9, and the digit 9 is **odd** → **dog** again.
- 7+9 = 16, whose digits are 1 (**odd**) then 6 (**even**) → **dog cat**.
- 11+17 = 28, whose digits are 2 (**even**) then 8 (**even**) → **cat cat**.

So: **dog = odd digit**, **cat = even digit**, and a string of animals shows the parity of each digit of the (normal) sum.

In the question we need:
1 + ? = (dog)(cat)(cat)
meaning the result must be a 3-digit number with digits (odd, even, even). The smallest such 3-digit number is **100** (1 odd, 0 even, 0 even).

Therefore the smallest ? is 100−1 = 99.

Treat each room as a point (vertex) and each doorway as a connection (edge). “Pass through each doorway once and only once” is exactly the condition for an Euler trail.

Key fact: In such a layout, an Euler trail can only start and finish in rooms that have an odd number of doorways connected to them (all other rooms must have an even number).

You enter through the front door into room F, so F is the starting room. Now count the doorways in each labeled room on the map:
- **F** has **3** doorways (one to G, and **two** different doorways leading into the central area/room D). → odd
- **E** has **3** doorways (one to G, and **two** different doorways leading into D). → odd
- The other rooms (A, B, C, D, G) each have an even number of doorways.

So the only odd-doorway rooms are **F** and **E**. Since you must start in **F**, the Euler-trail rule forces you to finish in the *other* odd room: **E**.

We need a time multiplication: **AB:CD × 3 = EF:G7** (the last digit is a fixed **7**, which is why 7 isn’t in the list of usable digits). Times are in mm:ss and seconds roll over at 60.

Work in seconds. Let the starting seconds be **S = 10C + D** and the result seconds be **Rsec = 10G + 7**.

1) **The ones digit forces D = 9.**
Only the ones digit matters mod 10:
- 3S ≡ 10G+7 (mod 10)
- 3(10C+D) ≡ 7 (mod 10) → 3D ≡ 7 (mod 10)
The only allowed digit D satisfying this is **D = 9** (since 3×9 = 27).

So **CD = C9**.

2) **Match seconds with base-60 rollover.**
Compute 3(C9) = 30C + 27 and split into “minutes carry k” and “remaining seconds”:
- If C=1: 30(1)+27 = 57 → seconds would be 57, so G=5 (but this later forces minutes too large).
- If C=4: 30(4)+27 = 147 = 120 + 27 → carry k=2 minutes and remaining seconds 27, so **G=2**.
(Choices C=2 gives G=2 but repeats digit 2; C=5 gives G=5 repeats digit 5, so they’re not allowed when each digit is used once.)

Thus **C=4, D=9, G=2**, and the seconds part becomes **49 × 3 = 147 sec = 2 min 27 sec**.

3) **Now handle minutes.**
Let starting minutes be **M = AB** and result minutes **N = EF**. Since the seconds multiplication contributed a carry of **k=2** minutes:
- N = 3M + 2
Remaining digits for A,B,E,F are {1,5,6,8}. The only M ≤ 59 using two of these that makes N a valid two-digit number using the remaining digits is:
- M = 18 → N = 3×18 + 2 = 56
This uses exactly the remaining digits (AB=18, EF=56).

So the full correct equation is **18:49 × 3 = 56:27**.

Treat each stick as a weightless balance beam hung by a string at its support point. If the weights on its two ends are equal (taking into account that an entire lower “sub-mobile” counts as the combined weight of all cans hanging from it), the stick would hang level. If one end is heavier, that end drops.

Start at the top stick:
- The top stick is pulled lower on the **right**, so the heavier can must be somewhere in the right-hand group (E–H).

Go down the right-hand group:
- The next stick down (the one holding the right group) has its **left** end lower, so the heavier can is in the left sub-group (E–G), not in H.
- The next stick down has its **left** end lower again, so the heavier can is in the (E–F) sub-group, not in G.
- The bottom stick in that chain (holding E and F) has its **right** end lower, meaning **F** is heavier than E.

Since only one can is filled with water, the can that must be heavier is **F**.

From the picture, bucket A is used on all three trips, B is used on trips 1 and 2, C is used on trips 2 and 3, and D and E are used on all three trips.

On the 1st trip, the two hands balance with A and B on one side and D and E on the other, so:
A + B = D + E
3 + 4 = D + E
D + E = 7.

Total water moved over the three trips is the sum of every bucket each time it appears:
- A appears 3 times: 3·3 = 9
- B appears 2 times: 2·4 = 8
- C appears 2 times: 2·C
- D and E together appear 3 times: 3·(D+E) = 3·7 = 21

So the total is:
9 + 8 + 2C + 21 = 52
38 + 2C = 52
2C = 14
C = 7.

Therefore bucket C must hold 7 gallons.

Each commute to the office takes 1 hour, and the job takes 2 more hours, so you’re ready to go home 3 hours after the bus you took to work departs.

Compute “ready to go home” time for each choice, then take the first listed home-bound bus that leaves at or after that time:
- A: 4:00 a.m. + 3 h = 7:00 a.m. → next home bus 10:30 a.m. → wait 3 h 30 m
- B: 9:00 a.m. + 3 h = 12:00 p.m. → next home bus 5:00 p.m. → wait 5 h
- C: 2:30 p.m. + 3 h = 5:30 p.m. → next home bus 8:00 p.m. → wait 2 h 30 m
- D: 6:00 p.m. + 3 h = 9:00 p.m. → next home bus 12:00 a.m. → wait 3 h
- E: 12:00 a.m. + 3 h = 3:00 a.m. → next home bus 5:00 a.m. → wait 2 h

The smallest waiting time is 2 hours, achieved by taking bus E to work.

Let the prices be: tea = t, juice = j, toast = o.

From the picture:
- Table 1 has 2 juices + 1 tea + 1 toast → total = 2j + t + o.
- Table 2 has 4 teas + 1 toast → total = 4t + o.
Since all tables have the same total:

2j + t + o = 4t + o  ⇒  2j = 3t.

Table 3 shows 2 juices + 3 teas (no toast) → total = 2j + 3t.
Substitute 2j = 3t:
Table 3 total = 3t + 3t = 6t.
So every table’s total is 6t.

Then for table 2: 4t + o = 6t  ⇒  o = 2t.

Table 4 shows 3 teas + 1 toast so far → 3t + o = 3t + 2t = 5t.
To reach the required 6t, the missing last item must add exactly t.
- Adding tea adds t (fits).
- Adding juice adds 1.5t (too much).
- Adding toast adds 2t (too much).

Therefore, the last item ordered at table 4 must be tea.

The watch’s date is made with a rotating date wheel. Around midnight, while the wheel is moving, the window can briefly show a “hybrid” made from the last (ones) digit of the outgoing date together with the first (tens) digit of the incoming date.

- **32** can appear when changing from **23 → 24**: the outgoing **23** contributes the **3**, and the incoming **24** contributes the **2**.
- **93** can appear when changing from **29 → 30**: the outgoing **29** contributes the **9**, and the incoming **30** contributes the **3**.
- **64** would require the incoming date to have a tens digit of **4** (i.e., a date in the 40s), but the watch only ever goes up to **31**, so no incoming date can start with 4.

Therefore, **64** is the only one that can never be seen, even during the date change.

All five trees lie on one straight line. The distance between any two trees on that line is the sum of the gaps between each neighboring pair of trees between them. To make that sum as large as possible, you must include every gap—meaning you must choose the two trees at the ends of the row. In the diagram, the leftmost tree is labeled A and the rightmost tree is labeled E, so those two are farthest apart.

The letters form the initials of the numbers in order: **O**ne, **T**wo, **T**hree, **F**our, **F**ive, **S**ix, **S**even, **E**ight, **N**ine, **T**en. The blank card is the 5th in the sequence, which corresponds to **Five**, so it must be **F**.

Each of the three key pieces is a fixed “handed” (chiral) shape because you are allowed to rotate them but **not** turn them over. In particular, the bent/notched geometry in the set can only make concave corners of one handedness.

When you try to assemble pieces 1, 2, and 3 to exactly fill each keyhole:
- **A, D, F, and G** can be tiled by rotating the pieces and joining them edge-to-edge; the required concave/stepped corner directions match the handedness of the available pieces.
- **B, C, and E** have the same kinds of outlines as other holes but in the **mirror** orientation (they’d require at least one piece to be flipped over to match the concave/step direction), so they cannot be formed with rotations alone.

Therefore, only the keyholes whose outlines are not mirror-dependent are usable.

Treat the display as four digits HHMM (the clock in the picture uses a leading 0 for 1–9), and ignore the colon when looking for “in a row”. With four digits, “three or more in a row” can only happen in two ways:

1) The last three digits match: H2 = M1 = M2.
This means the minutes must be “bb” where b is the hour’s second digit. But minutes can only be 00–59, so b must be 0–5.
That gives:
01:11, 02:22, 03:33, 04:44, 05:55, 10:00, 11:11, 12:22 → 8 times.

2) The first three digits match: H1 = H2 = M1.
The only hour with equal digits in 12-hour time is 11, so we need M1 = 1, i.e., 11:10 through 11:19 → 10 times.
(But 11:11 was already counted in case 1.)
So this contributes 9 additional times.

Total in one 12-hour cycle: 8 + 9 = 17.
A full day has two such cycles (AM and PM), so 17 × 2 = 34.

Use the fact that you have *two copies* of each letter.

- Take two **C**’s and flip one over (mirror it). Slide them together along their open sides. They fit neatly to make one complete **O-shaped ring** (a closed loop with the same thickness all around).
- Now take two **D**’s and do the same: flip one over and join them along their straight sides. They also form **the very same O-shaped ring**.

Since two C’s make exactly the same complete shape as two D’s, the total area of (C + C) equals the total area of (D + D). Therefore one C must have the same area as one D.

No measuring is needed—just matching the shapes made by pairing identical letters.

answer: The bottom-left picture (the glasses) cannot be drawn with one line.
justification:
A figure can be drawn in one continuous stroke (without retracing) exactly when its line-graph has **0 or 2 odd-degree vertices** (Euler trail rule). Corners, endpoints, and any place where three lines meet count as vertices.

In the **glasses** picture (bottom-left):
- Each arm has a free end → **2 endpoints**, degree 1 (odd).
- Each arm attaches to its lens at one point → **2 junctions** where 3 segments meet (around-the-lens splits into two directions + the arm) → degree 3 (odd).
- The bridge attaches to the lenses at two points → **2 more junctions** of degree 3 (odd).

That’s **6 odd vertices total**, which is more than 2, so it cannot be drawn with a single line.

The other three drawings can be arranged to have at most two odd vertices, so they are one-stroke drawable.

answer: Circle the bearded gentleman in the left-middle foreground wearing a blue hat and coat, holding a cane (the only one with a bow tie and no glasses).
justification: To find Mr. Anderson, match *all* the given clues at once: he must have **a beard**, **a hat**, **a cane**, and **a bow tie**, and he **must not be wearing glasses**. In the crowd, most people miss at least one detail (no cane, no beard, or they have glasses). The only person who clearly fits the full description is the **gentleman in the left-middle foreground** wearing a **blue hat** and **blue coat**, with a visible **beard**, holding a **cane**, and showing a small **bow tie** at his collar—**and he has no glasses**.

To clean every hall segment exactly once, the robot’s route must be an *Euler trail* on the hallway graph: use every corridor (edge) once, while intersections (vertices) may be visited again.

An Euler trail is only possible if **exactly two intersections have an odd number of corridors meeting there** (these become the start and the end); every other intersection must have even degree.

Looking at the map, **A is a dead end** (only one corridor leaves it), so it is an odd-degree intersection. Among the marked choices, **B, C, D, and E all have an even number of connected corridors**, so they cannot be endpoints of an Euler trail. The only other odd-degree intersection is an *unmarked* dead end elsewhere in the layout, which would be the finishing point.

Therefore, the only marked point that can be the start of a route that covers every corridor exactly once (and thus can be arranged to satisfy the “all turns left or all turns right” constraint by choosing the appropriate direction) is **A**.

Even though the clock face is blank, the fallen number tiles are still sitting around it in their proper circular order, so you can tell which direction is “12 o’clock” (the 12 tile is at the top, with 1 and 2 to its right, etc.).

With the dial orientation restored that way, read the hands normally: the longer (minute) hand points at the 2, which is 10 minutes, and the shorter (hour) hand points at the 8. لذلك the time shown is 8:10.

answer: Hide in the empty lion cage (top-left cage).
justification: The safest place is the escaped lion’s own cage (the empty cage). A lion cage is the one enclosure built sturdy enough to keep a lion from getting in or out; the only reason the lion escaped was because it was left unlocked.
