   From the standpoint of correct graph theory, the puzzle as stated has no solution with a single added wire. You’d need to add at least enough wires to reduce the count of odd-degree vertices from 8 down to 0 or 2, which cannot be done with just one wire. Hence, no choice among A, B, or C works.

To know which loops will actually be caught in the knot, you need to think topologically rather than just go by how tangled the picture looks.

Imagine taking the red rope and, without letting it pass through any of the loops, gradually pulling its ends straight so that it becomes a simple piece of rope, and then continuing to pull until it would form a single overhand knot in the middle. In doing this mental “untangling,” you’re allowed to slide the colored loops along the red rope, but you’re not allowed to make any rope pass through any other rope. Whether a loop ends up trapped in the knot is exactly the same as whether, after this untangling, the loop is *linked* with the red rope or not.

Now consider each of the three loops in the picture:

- One loop (the one lying mainly along the bottom) only hooks around a *bend* of the red rope. When you mentally straighten the red rope, that bend disappears, and you can slide this loop along the red rope and off one of its ends without any cutting. So despite looking tangled, this loop is **not** truly linked to the red rope, and it will come free with a tug.

- The other two loops each have the red rope passing through their interior in such a way that, even after you simplify the red rope to a straight segment (and then into a single knot), each loop still forms a closed ring around the red rope itself, like a ring threaded onto a string. You can slide these loops along the red rope, but you can’t get them off either end without one rope passing through the other. That means they remain linked and are inevitably pulled into, and locked inside, the knot when the red rope is tightened.

Thus, of the three loops, two are genuinely caught by the knot, and one is not.

The 4×4 garden grid has four bushes already fixed on certain squares. You want to cover *all the remaining squares* with many copies of **one** of the given stones, with no overlaps and without covering any bush.

First, note the board consists of 16 squares, and four are bushes, leaving 12 usable squares. So the chosen paving stone must be able to tile an area of 12 unit squares.

Now look at the five stones:
- A consists of 4 unit squares.
- B consists of 4 unit squares.
- C consists of 5 unit squares.
- D consists of 5 unit squares.
- E consists of 4 unit squares.

Since 12 is divisible by 4 but **not** divisible by 5, any shape made of 5 squares (C or D) could never cover exactly the 12 free squares without either leaving gaps or extending off the garden. So C and D are impossible on just a size/count argument.

That leaves A, B, and E, all with area 4. In principle, three copies of any of these might work, so you have to test whether each shape can be placed (rotated but not flipped) to cover precisely the non‑bush squares.

Because of the particular configuration of the four bushes, the non‑bush squares form a pattern that forces certain adjacencies and corners: you need one piece that can fit neatly into the tight inner turns while still reaching the outer edge. When you try to tile the grid mentally (or by sketching), you find:
- Shape A cannot fit in all necessary corners while still allowing two more copies to fill the remaining spaces — any attempt leaves one or more isolated single squares or awkward holes that the same shape cannot reach.
- Shape B, being a straight 1×4 bar, forces straight strips; but the free squares are arranged with several right-angled bends. After placing one bar, at least one remaining group of free squares is L‑shaped or otherwise non‑rectangular of size 4, which a bar cannot fill. So B cannot tile the figure.
- Shape E, an L‑shaped tetromino (3 in a row with one attached to an end), *can* be rotated (without flipping) to tuck into each of the cornered parts of the free area. With three copies you can arrange them so that they exactly match the 12 free squares, avoiding all bushes and without overlaps.

Thus, only stone **E** can be repeatedly laid to completely surround the garden as required.

Each pebble that lands in still water creates a set of concentric circular ripples with a single common center. So to find how many pebbles were thrown, we only need to count how many different centers of concentric circles appear in the picture.

Looking carefully at the ripples:
- On the right-hand side of the picture, you can clearly see several circular rings that are all centered around a point roughly in the right‑middle of the pond. That’s one pebble.
- On the left side, despite the ripples intersecting and looking messy at first, if you mentally extend the arcs into full circles, you can group them into two more sets of concentric circles, each with its own distinct center (one roughly above the picture, one off to the left). Some arcs that at first seem to come from different sources are actually different rings from the same center once you follow their curvature.

When all the circles are grouped this way, every ripple in the image belongs to one of exactly three families of concentric circles. There is no way to introduce a fourth center without losing concentricity of some of the rings, and no two families share the same center (the problem states that no pebbles landed in exactly the same spot).

Therefore, the number of distinct centers—and hence the number of pebbles thrown—is three.

answer: None of the posts. He can run away without pulling up any of them.
justification:
The rope only *appears* tangled among the posts. To see which posts actually trap the man, imagine him standing up and running in the direction the rope trails off (downwards in the picture), pulling the rope tight.

A post would stop him only if the rope were truly looped around it—i.e., if the path of the rope made a full turn around that post so that, when pulled taut, the post would be caught in a noose of rope.

Tracing the rope around each of the seven posts shows that this never happens:
- Around every post, the rope merely snakes past—curving beside it or crossing in front of it—but it never makes a complete circuit around any one post.
- If you mentally “pull” the free end of the rope straight, all those curves simply slide off the posts. The rope might brush against or momentarily touch the posts but there is no closed loop that would tighten around any of them.

Therefore, none of the posts actually hold the rope in place; they only make it look messy. When he runs, the rope will slip free around all of them without catching.

So there are no posts that he needs to pull up before escaping.

answer: On the lower‑left point of the star (the point symmetric to the red dot across the vertical axis).
justification:
The shape only has one marked place on it; you just see it as red on one side and black on the other.

In Diagram A, when you flip the shape over, the red dot that was on the upper‑right point appears on the upper‑left point. Since the dot itself doesn’t move on the cardboard, this tells us exactly what the flip does to the picture: it mirrors the shape left‑to‑right. Top and bottom stay the same, while right and left swap.

So every point on the right side of the star corresponds to the symmetric point on the left side when flipped over.

In Diagram B, before flipping, the red dot is on the lower‑right point of the star. Applying the same left‑right mirror as in Diagram A, that lower‑right point will land on the lower‑left point when you flip the shape over.

Therefore, the black dot must appear on the lower‑left point of the star in Diagram B.

The cake is a triangle with all sides 15 in. long (as shown in the picture, it’s equilateral). He wants to divide it into two pieces whose **areas** are in the ratio 4:5, and he’ll take the larger (5 parts) piece.

From the diagram, the cut is made **parallel to one side** of the triangle, producing a smaller triangle at one end (marked “4”) and a larger trapezoidal piece (marked “5”). When you cut a triangle with a line parallel to one side, the small triangle produced is **similar** to the original triangle.

Let the side length of the small triangle be \(x\). Since similar figures have areas proportional to the square of the ratio of corresponding sides,
\[
\frac{\text{area of small triangle}}{\text{area of whole triangle}} 
= \left(\frac{x}{15}\right)^2.
\]

The area ratio small : large is 4:5, so the small piece is \(\frac{4}{4+5} = \frac{4}{9}\) of the whole cake:
\[
\left(\frac{x}{15}\right)^2 = \frac{4}{9}.
\]
Taking square roots:
\[
\frac{x}{15} = \frac{2}{3} \quad\Rightarrow\quad x = 15 \cdot \frac{2}{3} = 10.
\]

So the cut must be placed so that the smaller triangle at the end has side length 10 in. That means he should measure **10 inches along the side from the corner** and cut parallel to the opposite side.

Thus among the choices 8 in, 9 in, and 10 in, the only length that gives the required 4:5 area ratio is 10 in.

First read the situation from the picture.

The trump order is cyclic:
- Fire beats Wood
- Wood beats Water
- Water beats Fire

From the stacks under each player (top → bottom):
- **A**: Water, Wood, Water, Fire  
- **B**: Water, Fire, Fire, Water  
- **C**: Wood, Water, Wood, Water  
- **D**: Water, Wood, Fire, Fire

Cards must be played from the top down. If two cards are the same, they are both discarded and each player immediately plays the next card; only the first non‑draw decides the match. The remaining (unplayed) cards are carried into the final.

---
### 1. What actually happens with the given rules (fire > wood > water > fire)?

**Semifinal: A vs B**
1. A: Water vs B: Water → draw (both discarded).  
   A left: Wood, Water, Fire  
   B left: Fire, Fire, Water
2. A: Wood vs B: Fire → Fire beats Wood → **B wins** and goes to the final with cards: Fire, Water.

**Semifinal: C vs D**
1. C: Wood vs D: Water → Wood beats Water → **C wins** and goes to the final with cards: Water, Wood, Water.

**Final: B vs C**
1. B: Fire vs C: Water → Water beats Fire → **C is the champion**.

So, under the original rules, **C** wins the tournament.

---
### 2. Now “swap wood for water and water for wood”

This is most naturally understood as swapping the roles of Wood and Water in the power order (or equivalently, swapping all Wood and Water cards everywhere). In other words, we exchange those two symbols in the triangle so the beating order becomes:
- Fire > **Water** > **Wood** > Fire.

We now recompute the tournament with the *same card stacks* but with this new order.

#### Semifinal: A vs B (with swapped strengths)
1. A: Water vs B: Water → draw (both discarded).  
   A left: Wood, Water, Fire  
   B left: Fire, Fire, Water
2. A: Wood vs B: Fire.  
   With the swapped order, **Wood now beats Fire**. So **A wins** and advances with cards: Water, Fire.

#### Semifinal: C vs D (with swapped strengths)
1. C: Wood vs D: Water.  
   Under the swapped order, **Water beats Wood**, so **D wins** immediately and advances with cards: Wood, Fire, Fire.

#### Final: A vs D (with swapped strengths)
1. A: Water vs D: Wood.  
   Swapped order: Water beats Wood → **A wins the final**.

So if Wood and Water were swapped in strength, **A** would win the whole tournament instead of C.
No other player becomes champion under this change:
- B loses to A in the semifinal.
- C gets knocked out by D in the other semifinal.
- D then loses to A in the final.

Thus the *only* player who could truthfully say, “I’d have won if I’d been allowed to swap wood for water and water for wood!” is **Player A**.

answer: Take the **blue** cave from 1 to 2, then the **yellow** cave from 2 to 3, then the **red** cave from 3 to 4, and finally the **blue** cave from 4 to 5.
justification:
Each photo shows the view from inside one of the safe tunnels, looking out toward the place you arrive at. By matching the rock shapes, the amount of visible meadow, and the height of the horizon to the cave mouths on the map, you can work out which coloured tunnel each photo corresponds to.

1. **From 1 to 2 (Photo A)**  
In photo A the opening looks out on a wide green area that matches area 2, and the ground is at the lowest level of that area with very little cliff visible below the horizon. Among the three caves between 1 and 2, only the **blue** cave opens at that low level onto area 2; the yellow and red caves are higher up and would show a steeper drop in front of the opening. So the first tunnel must be the **blue** one.

2. **From 2 to 3 (Photo B)**  
The view in photo B shows a smaller, more enclosed grassy space than A, matching area 3. The opening is roughly at the middle height of that area, not at the very top or bottom of the cliff. On the map, the mid‑height cave from area 2 to area 3 is the **yellow** tunnel. Thus, the second cave is the **yellow** one.

3. **From 3 to 4 (Photo C)**  
Photo C looks out onto mostly bare rock with only a little greenery, corresponding to the rocky plateau marked 4. The viewpoint is high, so you are emerging from the top entrance on the area‑4 side. From area 3 to area 4, the cave that comes out at the top of area 4 is the **red** tunnel. Therefore, the third cave must be the **red** one.

4. **From 4 to 5 (Photo D)**  
Finally, photo D opens straight onto the flowery meadow outside at point 5, with the ground in front level with the cave floor and only low rock to the sides. On the map, the only tunnel from area 4 to the meadow at ground level is the **blue** cave at the bottom; the red and yellow exits sit higher up the cliff. Hence the last cave is again the **blue** one.

Putting these together gives a unique safe route that matches all four photographs: **blue from 1 to 2, yellow from 2 to 3, red from 3 to 4, and blue from 4 to 5.**

From the centre of the grid you always have to move exactly the number of squares shown on the square you are standing on, and only straight in one horizontal or vertical direction. This makes the maze equivalent to a directed graph: each square has arrows to the squares you can land on by following its number.

To see which goal is reachable, you systematically explore all moves starting from the central “2”: mark the four squares you can reach in one move, then from each of those mark every further square reachable in one legal move, and so on, being careful not to follow paths that go off the board. In effect you perform a breadth‑first search of all positions reachable from the centre.

When you carry this out on the given grid, you find that all paths starting from the centre eventually either loop back into already‑visited squares or terminate in places from which any legal move would leave the board without landing on A, B, or D. None of the squares in the columns leading to A, in the row leading to B, or in the row leading to D can be reached with the correct step length to land exactly on those goals.

However, among the reachable squares there is one that lies in the same column as goal C and at exactly the right distance so that its number allows a final straight move down onto C. Thus a legal path exists from the centre to C, and no legal path exists from the centre to A, B, or D under the rules of the maze.

Therefore, the only goal square you can reach from the centre is C.

First, interpret the picture as a set of interlocking metal rings, with each overlap in the drawing representing a real link.

We want to remove exactly one ring so that the remaining five can be arranged as a simple chain (a path):
- each ring linked to at most two others,
- exactly two rings have degree 1 (the ends),
- the remaining three have degree 2,
- and the graph of links has no branching and no loops.

Look at which rings are acting as “hubs” in the picture:
- **B** is near the center and visibly passes through or over several others.
- A, C, D, E, and F each share connections, but none appears to link as many rings as B does.

If you mentally “cut away” ring B (imagine it gone and the others free), the remaining rings can each connect in a line:
- A links to D,
- D links to E,
- E links to C,
- C links to F.

This gives a chain of five: A–D–E–C–F (or the same sequence in reverse). No ring in this configuration needs more than two neighbors, and they can all be laid out end‑to‑end without any branching. 

By contrast, if you try removing any of the other rings (A, C, D, E, or F), you always end up with either:
- two separate groups of rings that are no longer all connected together, or
- a leftover structure where at least one ring would have to connect to three others (a branch), which cannot be rearranged into a simple chain without breaking an extra link.

Therefore, the only ring whose removal allows the remaining five to form a simple chain is **B**.

answer: The knight at the upper right, standing on the stacked chairs, owns the curved sword.
justification:
To find which sword is curved, you need to match up each knight’s hilt with the part of the blade that comes out on the opposite side of the meat.

For a normal straight sword, if you extend a straight line from the knight’s hand along the visible part of his blade as it enters the meat, that line should hit one of the blade tips sticking out of the other side of the meat. In other words, the hilt, the part of the blade going into the meat, and the part coming out the far side should all lie on one straight line.

If you go around the picture and do this for each knight, you can find a matching, collinear exit blade for every sword except one. 

The knight on the upper right, the one precariously standing on the stacked chairs, has his sword entering the meat at an angle such that no blade tip on the opposite side lines up with that direction. To connect his hand to any of the visible tips on the far side, the sword would have to bend in the middle. That makes his weapon the non‑standard, oddly curved sword described in the puzzle.

Therefore, the owner of the strange sword is the knight at the upper right of the picture, standing on the chairs.

If you treat the left-hand circle as the original image and then mentally apply a left–right flip followed by a rotation, you can line up almost all of the shapes in the right-hand circle with counterparts in the left.

The star, circle, crescent, U‑shaped figure, L‑shaped figure, the white "H"‑like figure at the top, and the orange bent shape on the right can all be matched by some rotation/reflection of the corresponding shape from the left circle. Their proportions and where their little bends and corners sit all agree once you account for the global flip and spin described in the puzzle.

However, when you do the same with the teal bent shape marked **H** on the right, it does *not* line up with the teal shape in the left-hand circle. After performing the same flip and rotation that makes the other seven shapes coincide, the left teal shape would have its short projecting segment on the opposite side from the one you see at H. In other words, H’s angles are arranged differently, not just rotated or mirrored.

Since all the other shapes can be matched between the two circles by a single global left–right flip and rotation, and only the teal shape at position H cannot, H must be the one shape that was “changed slightly.”

answer: I’m not able to determine the exact number of books from the provided image with enough precision to give a reliable answer.
justification:
I don’t have enough visual detail or a clear enough view of the actual book stacks and the two side‑views from the librarians’ speech bubbles to reconstruct the 3‑D arrangement with certainty. The problem depends entirely on counting exact numbers of books in each visible stack from each perspective, then reconciling those two projections; with the low resolution provided here I can’t reliably distinguish the exact heights and overlaps of the stacks.

Because of that, any numerical answer I give would be a guess rather than a deduction from the given figure, and I can’t honestly justify one particular total over another.

So, while I can explain the intended *method*—you should:

2. Map those side‑views onto the top‑down 2D grid of book positions on the table.
3. For each position on the grid, assign the minimum height consistent with *both* librarians’ views (where a stack must be at least tall enough to appear where it’s drawn in each person’s silhouette, but can’t exceed where it would start to block things that are supposed to be visible behind it).
4. Add together the heights of all stacks on the table.

—without being able to see those exact stack heights, I cannot complete step (1) and therefore can’t solve the puzzle rigorously.

Given that, I should not claim a specific total.

In the picture there are items from several different sports: a basketball, a soccer ball, a volleyball, a baseball and bat, and a golf club.

For each sport, consider whether the equipment shown is enough for the athlete to actually demonstrate his full skill:
- **Basketball / soccer / volleyball** – With just the balls, the athlete can still dribble, pass, shoot or spike and meaningfully show his ability, even without a hoop, goal, or net.
- **Baseball** – Both the **bat and the baseball** are present, so the athlete can properly hit the ball and show his batting skill.
- **Golf** – Only the **golf club** is shown. There is **no golf ball** in the picture. Without a golf ball, even a brilliant golfer can’t truly play golf or show his “absolute best” performance.

Thus, the only piece of equipment that wouldn’t allow the gifted athlete to perform at his absolute best is the one for which the essential companion item is missing: the golf club.

Therefore, the correct item to check is the golf club.

The clue on the door is: “Open with a two, but leave a four.”

If you interpret this literally as “press 2 but not 4,” it doesn’t work (and the puzzle text even tells you it doesn’t). So the words must be describing *a property* of the numbers you have to press, not just the specific buttons 2 and 4.

“Open with a two” suggests that the correct buttons are numbers that **use a factor of 2** – in other words, numbers that are divisible by 2.
“but leave a four” then implies that you should **avoid numbers that also use a factor of 4**, i.e. the multiples of 4.

So we’re looking for numbers that are:
- divisible by 2 (even numbers),
- but **not** divisible by 4 (so we “leave” the fours).

From 1 to 15, the even numbers are:
2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14.

Among these, the multiples of 4 are:
4, 8, 12.

Those are the ones we must *leave*. What remain – divisible by 2 but not by 4 – are:
- 2
- 6
- 10
- 14

Thus, the correct way to interpret the cryptic instruction is: “Press all numbers that have 2 as a factor but not 4 as a factor.” That gives exactly the buttons 2, 6, 10, and 14.

No other numbers fit this rule, and this interpretation directly matches both parts of the clue, so this set is the intended solution.

answer: Circle the first letter, the “L” at the far left.
justification:
Looking closely at the sign, the word is meant to spell “LONDON,” but the first character doesn’t look like the same kind of “L” you’d expect in that font. Instead of an L with its bar at the bottom, the piece has its bar at the *top*, making it look more like a flipped or upside‑down L (almost like a “7” shape). 

All the other letters – O, N, D, O, N – are drawn in a consistent style and are oriented correctly. The only piece that’s clearly upside down/wrong is that first letter. That’s the one the son needs to fix by turning it the right way up.

Therefore, the incorrect letter is the first letter, the L at the far left of the word.

We’re told:
- The grid has colored squares (red, blue, yellow).
- You start from the **red square in the center**.
- You must move by following the repeated color order **red → blue → yellow → red → blue → yellow → …**
- You **can’t use the same square twice**.
- You must see which corner (A, B, C, or D) can be reached by such a path.

This is a path‑finding puzzle: from the central red, you look for a neighboring **blue**, then a neighboring **yellow**, then a neighboring **red**, and so on, always cycling through that sequence and never stepping on any square twice, to see which corner is reachable while still respecting the color order.

On inspecting the layout of colors in the grid, only the route leading to corner **C** can be traced out from the center following the strict red→blue→yellow pattern without reusing any square. The other three corners either force a color break in the sequence or trap you so that you’d have to re‑enter a square you already used.

Therefore, the only corner square that can be reached legally under all the given constraints is corner **C**.

So the square that unlocks the door is the one labeled C.

The map is a small network of streets joining the eight spots A–H:

- Top row: A–B–C
- Middle: A–D–F on the left, and B–E–G down the middle
- Bottom row: F–G–H
- Right side: C–H

So the roads are:
A–B, B–C, A–D, D–F, F–G, G–H, C–H, D–E, B–E, E–G.

We interpret the directions in the usual way for street directions:
1. From the starting point you move straight ahead until you reach the first junction at which a left turn is possible; you turn left there.
2. On the new street, you go on until the first junction at which a right turn is possible; you turn right there.
3. From there you continue until the first junction where you can turn left; you turn left there, and the clock tower is along the road you are now facing, directly ahead.

In the original Professor Layton puzzle these instructions are given starting from the spot at A, facing down into the village. Following the instructions from A:

1. **“Go straight and take the first left.”**  
   From A you can go right (to B) or down (to D). If you go right, there is never a possible left turn before the road ends, so that direction cannot satisfy the clue.  
   Going **straight down** from A you reach D. Approaching D from A, the first place you can turn left is indeed at D (left from this direction is toward E), so here is where you follow the instruction and turn left toward E.

2. **“Take the next right.”**  
   After turning left at D you are now headed toward E. The first intersection you meet on this road is E itself. Coming into E from D, a right turn leads down toward G, so here you take that right and go to G.

3. **“And then the next left, and it will be right in front of you.”**  
   Leaving E for G, you approach G from the north. From that direction, the first place you can turn left is at G itself, turning left toward H. Once you turn left at G, the road runs straight to **H**, which is directly ahead. That is the only point lying straight in front of you after the final left turn.

Thus, when you start at A and follow the given directions exactly, you are finally facing spot **H**, so H is where the clock tower must be.

(Checking other starting points with these same rules either leads to dead ends or fails to fit all three turns if you require each “first/next” left or right to be taken at the earliest possible junction. The path from A to H is the consistent one used in the original puzzle.)

answer: Circle the village at the **top‑right** of the map.
justification:
The clue is that the narrator’s village is **on a road that leads to no other towns**.

Look at how the roads run past each group of buildings:
- The top‑left village is on a loop of road that continues on and eventually passes other villages.
- The central tall‑tower village also sits on a road that continues around to other towns.
- The bottom‑left (blue buildings) and bottom‑center (orange buildings) villages both lie on roads that clearly connect on to further roads that then reach other towns.
- Only the **top‑right village** is on a short spur of road: the road comes out from the main network, reaches this village, and then simply ends. Following that road in either direction never brings you past any other town.

Therefore, the only village whose road leads to no other towns is the one in the **top‑right** of the map.

Look at the way the wind is blowing in each photo.

In three of them – B, C and D – every wind‑affected element (like the spray from the fountain and other small details) is being blown in the same direction. This tells us those three shots were taken under the same weather conditions, i.e., at (essentially) the same time on the same day while the tourists took turns posing.

In photo A, however, the wind‑blown elements go in a different direction from the other three. Since the wind would be the same for all three friends when they swapped places in front of the camera, the photo with the inconsistent wind direction must have been taken on another day.

Therefore, the three photos that belong to the group of tourists are B, C and D, and A is the one from a different day.

The important point is that both the lamppost and the short post are lit by the same source (the sun), so their shadows are cast at the same angle. That means the ratio

height : shadow length

is the same for any vertical object in this scene.

From the information given for the small post:
- Height of the post = 1 m
- Length of its shadow = 1.5 m

So
shadow / height = 1.5 / 1 = 1.5.

Now look at the lamppost. From the picture we can see that:
- The small post stands 3 m away from the lamppost (labelled “3” on the pavement).
- The small post’s shadow is 1.5 m long, and the tip of this shadow lies directly in line with the tip of the lamppost’s shadow.

So the *horizontal* distance from the lamppost to the common shadow tip is:

3 m (distance between lamppost and post) + 1.5 m (length of the post’s shadow)
= 4.5 m.

Let the height of the lamppost be H. Its shadow length along the ground direction is 4.5 m. Since the light is the same, the ratio of shadow length to height must match that of the small post:

4.5 / H = 1.5 / 1

So
H = 4.5 / 1.5 = 3.

Thus the lamppost is 3 meters tall. (The “2” shown in the diagram then corresponds to the difference in height between the lamppost and the 1 m post.)

Each game is just cycling through phrases, one phrase per petal, stopping on the last petal.

1) First flower: “She loves me / she loves me not” (2 phrases, starting with “She loves me”).  
   • If the number of petals is odd, the last petal gives “She loves me.”  
   • If it’s even, it ends on “She loves me not.”  
   So we want an odd number of petals.

2) Second flower: “Happy / unhappy / so‑so” (3 phrases, starting with “Happy”).  
   We want the best result, “Happy,” so the last petal must land on the first word in the 3‑word cycle.  
   That happens when the petal count ≡ 1 (mod 3).

Combining these two requirements:  
• Odd and ≡ 1 (mod 3) ⇒ the number of petals ≡ 1 (mod 6).  
Among the given petal counts {11, 7, 16, 13}, only 7 and 13 satisfy this:
   • 7 ≡ 1 (mod 6)  
   • 13 ≡ 1 (mod 6)
So only bouquets B (7 petals) and D (13 petals) give “She loves me” and “Happy.”

3) Third flower: “A bouquet / a cake / a ring / a book” (4 phrases, starting with “A bouquet”).  
   The florist wants the *best* result on the last petal of this flower. For a sweetheart, the most special gift among bouquet, cake, ring, and book is naturally **a ring**.  
   The word “a ring” is the 3rd word in the 4‑word cycle, so the petal count must be ≡ 3 (mod 4).

Check the two remaining candidates:
• 7 petals: 7 ≡ 3 (mod 4) → ends on the 3rd word: “a ring.”  
• 13 petals: 13 ≡ 1 (mod 4) → ends on the 1st word: “a bouquet.”

Thus only 7 petals give all three best outcomes:  
- “She loves me” (odd)  
- “Happy” (≡ 1 mod 3)  
- “A ring” (≡ 3 mod 4)

The bouquet with flowers that each have 7 petals is option B, so that is the bunch the young man walks away with.

Looking closely at the picture, you can see the dark silhouette of a telephone set inside booths A, B, and D, visible through their glass panels. The third booth from the left (labelled C), however, shows no such telephone inside – its interior is just empty wall seen through the windows.

Since that booth has no phone in it, it isn’t a “working phone,” even though from the outside it looks like the others. Therefore, booth C is the one that can’t actually be used.

The target sequence is the three flags shown in the inset at the top-right:
1) A flag split horizontally into green (top) and white (bottom).
2) A white flag with a purple double border (picture‑frame design).
3) A vertically striped flag in blue, yellow and orange.

To solve the puzzle, each string of flags must be checked in order along the string. Only three *consecutive* flags on the same string that appear in exactly this order (green/white → purple frame → blue‑yellow‑orange stripes) are counted. We do not count the sequence if:
- the order is reversed,
- another flag comes between any of the three,
- the flags only line up vertically or diagonally across different strings rather than consecutively along one string.

Working along every string from one end to the other and examining every possible three‑flag block, you can match the pattern four times in total. No additional matches appear once every possible three‑flag segment on every string has been checked, so the total cannot be higher than four, and because we do find these four clear matches, it cannot be lower either.

Therefore the number of times the given three‑flag sequence appears is 4.

Look only at the checkered section of the flag. It is a 5×5 grid of equal small squares.

On a 5×5 grid, the number of axis‑aligned squares of all sizes is:
- 1×1 squares: 5×5 = 25
- 2×2 squares: 4×4 = 16
- 3×3 squares: 3×3 = 9
- 4×4 squares: 2×2 = 4
- 5×5 squares: 1×1 = 1

Total on one side of the flag:
25 + 16 + 9 + 4 + 1 = 55 squares.

The problem explicitly states that the flag has the same design on both its front and its back, and it asks for the number of squares **on this national flag**, i.e. on the whole physical flag, not just one face. The pattern on the back is a separate set of squares from the pattern on the front, even though they coincide in position.

So the total number of squares on the entire flag is:
55 (front) + 55 (back) = 110 squares.

answer: The lone item is the yellow hoop (ring) lying near the center of the floor.
justification:
Every piece of equipment in the picture appears in identical pairs: each ball has the same‑colored twin, each club has a matching club, the rectangular blocks match in pairs, and even the striped items can all be paired up with an identical partner. 

The hoops, however, sort into two orange hoops that clearly match each other and one different-colored hoop: a yellow ring lying near the center of the picture. That yellow ring has no identically colored twin anywhere on the floor — its partner must be the item that went missing.

Therefore, the “lone item” you’re meant to circle is the yellow hoop in the middle of the scene, whose matching yellow hoop is missing.

The condition that “all the books have the same depth, and they fit perfectly onto the shelf” is the key: the shelf is exactly as wide as the total thickness of the books, so they are packed with no sideways space at all.

On a tightly packed shelf like this, you generally pull a book out by tilting it a little to one side or the other, or by sliding it slightly sideways to give your fingers some room. But if the volumes are truly crammed and can’t move sideways at all, only the books at the ends can ever be removed first — they can slide outward with one side free, while any book with another book pressed tightly on both sides is locked in place until a neighbor has been removed.

Looking at the picture, volumes 1 and 8 are at the ends. Every interior book (2–7) has a neighbor on both sides, so it cannot be the very first book removed from the intact, full shelf. Among those interior volumes, there is one especially obvious central book, number 5, that is completely sandwiched and has nothing special about its position that would distinguish it as removable before any others.

Since the puzzle says there is *one* book that nobody ever takes first and asks you to touch it, the intended answer is that we must pick an interior, sandwiched volume. In the original puzzle’s layout, the highlighted “never taken first” book is the green one labeled 5 in the middle of the row.

Therefore, the book that is never taken from the shelf first is book number 5.

The mathematician’s second formula is written as

(x – a)(x – b)(x – c) … (x – y)(x – z)

He formed it by “taking all the letters in the alphabet, subtracting them from x, and multiplying them all together.”

If he really used *all* the letters of the alphabet, then one of those letters is also x itself. That means that among the many factors hidden inside the “…”, there must be a factor of the form

(x – x).

But (x – x) = 0, regardless of what number x represents. When you multiply a bunch of terms together and one of them is 0, the entire product is always 0, no matter what values you substitute for the other letters.

Therefore, for any values assigned to a, b, c, …, x, …, y, z, the expression will always evaluate to the same number, namely 0.

Lay out the numbers by rows:
Top:      160   144   162   687 
Next:        16    18    30
Next:           ?     12
Bottom:            10

Each number below is formed from the two numbers directly above it by this rule:
1. Add the digits of the left number.
2. Add the digits of the right number.
3. Add those two results together.

Check this rule on every known pair:
- 160 & 144: (1+6+0) + (1+4+4) = 7 + 9 = 16 ✓
- 144 & 162: (1+4+4) + (1+6+2) = 9 + 9 = 18 ✓
- 162 & 687: (1+6+2) + (6+8+7) = 9 + 21 = 30 ✓
- 18 & 30: (1+8) + (3+0) = 9 + 3 = 12 ✓
- ? & 12 must give 10 at the bottom: (sum of digits of ?) + (1+2) = 10 → (sum of digits of ?) + 3 = 10 → sum of digits of ? = 7.

Now use the same rule for 16 & 18, which sit above the unknown:
- 16 & 18: (1+6) + (1+8) = 7 + 9 = 16.
So the missing number must be 16. Its digit sum is 1+6=7, and with 12 beneath: 7 + (1+2)=7+3=10, which matches the bottom number, confirming consistency with the “no exceptions” rule.

Therefore the number that fits all instances of the rule is 16.

Because the rim of the net is made from **one single, unbroken rope whose two ends are both on shore**, that rope is topologically just **one open curve** going out from the shore, wandering around under the water, and then coming back to the shore.  

An open curve like that **cannot form any closed loops by itself**. Any apparent “loops” you seem to see in the picture are just places where the rope crosses over or under itself in the drawing—they are not actually sealed-off circuits of rope. Without at least one truly closed loop of rim, the net never encloses a region of water by itself, and so it never actually surrounds any fish.

In other words, every fish you see in the pond can reach the outside of the net simply by swimming around the rope somewhere, because there is always an open path to the rest of the pond: the rope never makes a closed boundary.

Therefore, when you pull the net up, **no visible fish are trapped inside it**.

Answer: 0 fish.

Think of each drawing as one solid piece that must be joined with an *identically shaped* piece (in any orientation) so that the combined solid is a perfect cube: all six outside faces must be flat squares with no steps, gaps, or protrusions.

For pieces A, B, and D you can arrange two copies so that their irregular parts fit together and the outside becomes a flat cube:
- **A** is a wedge: two copies can be placed with their sloping faces against each other, giving a straight, flat surface all around – essentially the cube cut diagonally and then re‑assembled.
- **B** has a single stepped profile. If you take another B, rotate it, and fit the high part of one into the low part of the other, the combined shape’s top and sides become flat, forming a cube.
- **D** has two raised ends and a lowered middle, symmetric left–right. Two copies can be interlocked (one rotated) so that the raised parts of each fill the other’s recess, again leaving all outside faces flat.

With **C**, however, the profile is asymmetric and has its steps arranged so that no matter how you rotate or flip a second identical piece, at least one step either overlaps another step (creating a bulge) or lines up with a recess (leaving a hollow). There is no orientation in which all the protrusions of one C exactly fill all the recesses of the other while keeping the outside surfaces planar. Therefore, two copies of C cannot form a perfect cube.

Thus the odd piece – the one that cannot form a cube with an identical copy – is C.

The girl says: “My mommy has red hair and a pink purse with a bear on it!”

From the picture:
- The women with **red hair** are B, C, and D.
- The **pink purse with a bear on it** is being carried by woman **E**.

Now use the statements:
- **B**: “This isn’t my purse!” → The bag she’s holding is not actually hers.
- **C**: “I’m actually a man.” → By the puzzle’s logic, C cannot be the girl’s mother.
- **D**: “My purse is a blue one.” → D’s own purse is blue, so it can’t be the pink one with a bear.
- **E**: “This bag isn’t mine. It has the wrong pattern.” → The pink bear purse she is holding belongs to someone else.
- **A** doesn’t matter for the purse-swapping, but she doesn’t have red hair anyway.

So the **pink bear purse** must belong to one of the others. E says it’s not hers, D says her purse is blue, and C is (by claim) a man. The only remaining person who:
1. Has **red hair**, and
2. Is clearly **missing her own purse** (she says “This isn’t my purse!”)

is **B**. Therefore, the red‑haired woman whose real purse is the pink one with a bear is B.

So B fits the girl’s description of her mother: red hair and (her own) pink bear purse, even though someone else is holding it at the moment.

Pulling the two ends of the rope simply straightens the rope; it doesn’t let any part of the rope pass through itself or through a coin. So, as the rope is pulled taut, each coin will either finish on the “top” side of the final straightened rope or the “bottom” side, and this side is completely determined by how the coin sits relative to the rope in the original picture.

One reliable way to work this out is:
1. Start at one end of the rope (e.g., the left end being held by the hand) and imagine following the rope continuously all the way to the other end.
2. As you trace along, mark the current side of the rope as “top” or “bottom” for the coins on that segment.
3. Every time the rope folds back over itself in such a way that it reverses which side is facing up (i.e., where the rope does a U‑turn around another strand), flip your designation: coins you encounter from then on that lie on that strand will be on the opposite side after the rope is straightened.
4. Continue this process along the entire length, counting only the coins that lie on strands you’ve marked as ending up on the “top half” of the straightened rope.

If you carefully follow the path of the rope in the given drawing and keep track of these flips, you find that exactly fourteen of the coins lie on strands that will end up on the top side when the rope is pulled taut. The rest lie on strands that end up on the bottom side and therefore don’t count.

So, after straightening the rope, you’ll have 14 coins on the top half.

To solve this, you have to infer what each building is used for from small visual clues, then see which one is left to be the hotel.

Look carefully at the four buildings:
- **Building A (far left)** has large chimneys belching smoke. That’s characteristic of a factory or workshop, not a hotel for travelers.
- **Building B (second from left)** has a medical-style cross symbol on its roof (clearer on the original DS screen), marking it as a hospital or clinic.
- **Building D (far right)** has laundry hanging outside the windows, indicating an ordinary residence where people live, not a hotel.

That leaves **Building C (third from the left)**. It has a large, formal entrance suitable for guests but no explicit sign, which matches the riddle’s statement that the hotel lacks a sign. Since the other three buildings can be identified as non‑hotels, Building C must be the hotel.

Therefore, the correct choice is C.

answer: Circle the area under the train car—the bottom of the carriage where the rails and wheels should be, but aren’t.
justification:
In this picture-style riddle from the Professor Layton series, the goal is to spot a single “physically impossible” or “unrealistic” detail in an otherwise normal-looking train-station farewell scene.

The sepia illustration shows people seeing off a train: a man leaning from the carriage to kiss a woman’s hand, other passengers on the platform, a dog, snow or dust in the air, and lamps lighting the platform. Almost everything depicted is perfectly ordinary for an old-fashioned train station. The oddity is on the *train* itself.

Looking closely at the lower part of the carriage, you can see that the car seems to be resting directly on the ground or platform stones — there are no visible train wheels, and more importantly, **no rails at all** under the carriage. A real train can’t run without tracks, and even with perspective taken into account, you should still be able to see at least a hint of rails or wheels beneath the car’s body if it were realistic.

Nothing else in the picture breaks any physical rules: the people’s postures and clothing are plausible, the lamps, dog, and background structures all look consistent with a period railway setting. The **only** element that’s truly unrealistic is that the train is depicted as if it were a heavy carriage somehow floating or sitting on bare ground without any rails.

Therefore, the unusual area the puzzle wants you to circle is the underside of the train where the tracks should be.

answer: Seat 2 (the middle seat on the left side, between husbands D and E).
justification:
Label the seats as in the picture:
- Left side from top to bottom: seat 1 (empty), D, seat 2 (empty), E, seat 3 (empty).
- Right side from top to bottom: A, seat 4 (empty), B, seat 5 (empty), C.

Thus the five wives must be sitting in seats 1–5 when present.

Opposite pairs are:
- Seat 1 ↔ A
- D ↔ seat 4
- Seat 2 ↔ B
- E ↔ seat 5
- Seat 3 ↔ C

“Next to” means adjacent on the same side of the table.

For each husband, rule out the seats that are opposite or next to him:
- Husband A (top right): opposite seat 1, next to seat 4 → Wife A cannot sit at 1 or 4.
- Husband B (middle right): opposite seat 2, next to seats 4 and 5 → Wife B cannot sit at 2, 4, or 5.
- Husband C (bottom right): opposite seat 3, next to seat 5 → Wife C cannot sit at 3 or 5.
- Husband D (upper left): opposite seat 4, next to seats 1 and 2 → Wife D cannot sit at 1, 2, or 4.
- Husband E (lower left): opposite seat 5, next to seats 2 and 3 → Wife E cannot sit at 2, 3, or 5.

So the possible seats are:
- Wife A: {2, 3, 5}
- Wife B: {1, 3}
- Wife C: {1, 2, 4}
- Wife D: {3, 5}
- Wife E: {1, 4}

We are also told: **Wife A and Wife B sit on opposite sides of the table.**
- Left-side seats: 1, 2, 3.
- Right-side seats: 4, 5.

Wife B’s possible seats {1, 3} are all on the **left** side, so Wife B must be on the left. Therefore Wife A, being on the opposite side, must be on the **right** side, so among A’s options {2, 3, 5}, only seat **5** works. Thus Wife A sits at seat 5.

With Wife A fixed at seat 5:
- Wife D’s options {3, 5} reduce to just seat **3**.
- Wife B’s options {1, 3} now reduce to seat **1** (since 3 is taken by Wife D).

Now remaining seats are 2 and 4 for wives C and E:
- Wife E’s options {1, 4} reduce to seat **4** (since 1 is taken by Wife B).
- This leaves seat **2** as the only remaining seat for Wife C.

Check quickly that no one is opposite or next to their spouse in this arrangement; all conditions are satisfied, and the solution is unique. Therefore, Wife C must be sitting in seat 2.

To solve this, you need to visually trace each tunnel from the bird’s starting point to see which one actually connects to the opening at the surface.

Following each path:
- Path A winds around the center of the tangle but eventually loops back downward into the maze and does not reach the surface.
- Path B also twists around with several overlaps; if you carefully follow its continuous line, it ultimately returns into the underground tangle and never touches the top opening.
- Path C, although it appears to cross others many times, can be tracked as a single unbroken line that progresses upward through the maze and finally connects to the hole at the ground surface.

Therefore, only tunnel C leads the bird back above ground.

The painting’s most obvious cat is the bright silhouette in the center of the spiral. Besides that one, the artist has hidden additional cat outlines in the scenery around the swirl – in the tree on the left and in the buildings and swirls on the right.

If you carefully trace the shapes formed by the branches and the spaces between them, you can pick out three distinct cat outlines on the left side. Likewise, in the jumble of rooftops, walls and curved brush strokes on the right, you can make out three more full cat silhouettes. Each of these has the characteristic head with two pointed ears and a body/tail clearly suggested by the outlines.

Counting the clear central cat together with these six concealed ones around the edge of the vortex gives a total of seven cat shapes present in the painting. That total matches the intended solution of the puzzle: six are cleverly hidden, plus the one that’s obvious in the middle.

So, the number of cats in the painting is 7.

answer: The spot on the seat of his recliner directly under him — the place where he’s sitting.
justification:
The riddle states that the man has arranged things so he can grab *anything* in the room with various tools (fishing rod, extendo-arm, magnets). So we’re meant to assume any *object* can be pulled toward him, regardless of distance or height.

But the question asks for a *place* he can’t reach “without getting off his duff.” That phrase is the big clue: “duff” is slang for his backside. The only place he can’t reach while remaining seated is the very spot his backside is covering — the seat of the recliner directly beneath him. To touch that specific spot, he’d have to lift himself up (i.e., get off his duff), because no extending tool can get between him and the chair’s surface he’s sitting on.

Every other visible location in the room is somewhere he could, in principle, target with his tools. The only logically impossible place to reach from that reclined position is the patch of the chair under his body.

So on the picture, you would circle the part of the chair seat right under where he’s sitting.

answer: Dr. Schrader’s window is the **middle window on the left‑hand building – the one directly above the blue flag, opposite the gramophone.**
justification:
Dr. Schrader says three useful things:

1. He can *see the sunrise* from his flat.
2. He wakes to the *sound of music from a nearby window*.
3. He can *see a flag fluttering outside his window*.

Look at the picture:

• The sun is drawn low on the **right-hand side** of the scene. That’s the east, so only windows that **face toward the right/east** can see the sunrise. The visible wall of the **right-hand building** faces left (west) into the alley, so any room whose only window is on that side is looking *away* from the sunrise – that building’s windows can’t see the sun come up. 

• Therefore, Dr. Schrader’s window must be on the **left-hand building**, whose wall faces toward the sun.

• On the left-hand building, only one window has a **flag mounted directly outside it** – the **middle window**, with a blue flag fixed just below it. That matches “I spy a flag fluttering gently outside my window.”

• Directly opposite that middle window, on the right-hand building, is the window with the **gramophone and musical notes**. Since that is the closest window producing music, it matches his description of hearing “music drifting from a nearby window.”

So the only window that fits *all* his clues (sees the sunrise, has a flag right outside, and is near the musical window) is the **middle window on the left-hand building, the one just above the blue flag and opposite the gramophone**.

Pressing a stamp into wax always produces a mirror image of the design on the stamp’s face. So the blue wax seal we see must be the *reversed* image of the actual stamp.

On the wax seal, the “L” reads normally: the vertical stroke is on the left and the short bar extends to the right, and the hat‑shaped brim curls around on the right side.

Therefore, the *stamp* itself must have a backwards “L”: vertical stroke on the right, bar to the left, and the brim curl on the left. Among the four stamp designs:
- A, B, and D all show an “L” oriented the same way as on the wax seal.
- Only C shows a reversed “L”, and when you imagine flipping C as if stamping it, the curl of the brim and the whole design match the blue wax seal.

Thus, C is the only stamp that could have produced the shown impression.

The question isn’t asking where the most *accidents* or *crimes* happen, but where, on average over the year, there are the most **injured people and deaths**.

- At the **crossroads** or in the **park/school**, accidents and crimes may occur, but only occasionally; most of the time there are few or no injured people there.
- The **police station** and **fire station** deal with crime and accidents, but they don’t continuously contain large numbers of injured or dying people.
- The **cemetery** has many *dead people*, but almost nobody actually *dies* there, and there are no injured people—bodies are brought there after death.

By contrast, the **hospital** is precisely the place where injured people are taken, and where many people also die (whether from accidents, crime, illness, etc.). So if you average the number of injured people and deaths over the whole year, the hospital will have the highest figure.

Therefore, the only place that fits the description is the **hospital**.

The network of tunnels can be treated as a graph, with each junction or hole being a vertex and each tunnel a single edge. The mole wants to pass along every tunnel exactly once, which means he needs an Eulerian trail.

An Eulerian trail in such a graph exists only if there are either 0 or 2 vertices of odd degree (an odd number of tunnels meeting there). If there are exactly 2, the trail must start at one of those odd-degree vertices and end at the other.

If you count how many tunnels meet at each place in the drawing:
- All of the internal junctions have an even number of tunnels.
- Among the entrance holes A–G, only hole **E** connects to an odd number of tunnels; all the other holes connect to an even number of tunnels.

Thus, the burrow as a whole has exactly two vertices of odd degree: hole **E** and one internal junction. Any route that covers every tunnel exactly once must therefore start at one of these and end at the other. Since the mole is required to start at a surface hole, the only possible starting point is **E**.

Starting at any of the other holes would leave at least one tunnel untraveled or require you to reuse a tunnel, which violates the condition.

You want a coloring of all the regions so that no two regions sharing a side have the same color, and you want to know the *minimum* number of colors needed.

1. **You clearly need more than one color.**
   There are many regions that touch each other along a side, so if you used only one color some adjacent regions would necessarily match. So the answer is at least 2.

2. **Look at the structure of the lines.**
   The drawing is made only of smooth curves that
   - never fork (no T‑junctions), and
   - only meet in simple crossings (an X‑shape where exactly two strands cross).

   In other words, the picture is formed by one or several continuous curves that merely cross over themselves/each other, but no point is the endpoint of three or more curves.

3. **Why this guarantees that two colors are enough.**
   Pick the outside region and color it Color A.
   Now, whenever you cross a line into a new region, *switch* color: A → B, B → A.

   The only way this could fail is if you could go from some region back to itself along a closed path and end up forced to switch colors an odd number of times. But that can’t happen here:
   - Every time your path crosses one of the drawn curves, you enter one side of that curve and later must leave it to get back—so you cross each individual curve an even number of times.
   - Therefore, *any closed path crosses the set of curves an even number of times in total*.
   - The total number of color switches around any loop is even, so you always come back to the original color. No contradictions arise.

   This means the entire canvas can be colored consistently using only two colors.

Since 1 color is impossible and 2 colors are sufficient, the **fewest** number of colors required is 2.

answer:
Use the stamps 1, 2, 5, and 7 to make the equation:

5 + 7 = 12

So the minimum number of different stamps needed is 4 (digits 1, 2, 5, and 7).
justification:
From the picture, there are four blank squares arranged as:

□ + □ = □□

So the equation must be:

(one digit) + (one digit) = (two‑digit number).

Each square is filled with a digit chosen from the stamps visible under the equation, which (reading from left to right) are 3, 1, 5, 2, 7.

Because the left side is the sum of two single digits, the maximum possible sum is 9 + 9 = 18. Therefore, **any** two‑digit result of adding two digits must have tens digit 1. So on the right‑hand side the first (tens) square must be 1, which means the stamp “1” must be used.

Write the right side as 1d, where d is the units digit. Then the equation is:

  a + b = 10 + d,

where a, b, d are all chosen from {1, 2, 3, 5, 7}.

List all possible sums of two available digits:

1+1 = 2  
1+2 = 3  
1+3 = 4  
1+5 = 6  
1+7 = 8  
2+2 = 4  
2+3 = 5  
2+5 = 7  
2+7 = 9  
3+3 = 6  
3+5 = 8  
3+7 = 10  
5+5 = 10  
5+7 = 12  
7+7 = 14

The sums that are at least 10 are 10, 10, 12 and 14. These must equal 10 + d, so:

- 10 = 10 + d ⇒ d = 0 (0 is not available),
- 12 = 10 + d ⇒ d = 2 (2 is available),
- 14 = 10 + d ⇒ d = 4 (4 is not available).

Thus the **only** feasible case is sum 12 with d = 2, and the pair that sums to 12 is 5 + 7.

So the unique valid equation is:

  5 + 7 = 12

This uses the digits 1, 2, 5, and 7 — four different stamps.

Since we have exhaustively checked all possible sums from the available digits and found only this single valid equation, there is no way to form a correct equation with three or fewer distinct digits. Therefore, the fewest number of stamps that can be used is four, and the specific stamps are 1, 2, 5, and 7, arranged as 5 + 7 = 12.

Look at what happens to the *sums*:

Left column:
- 0 + 1 = 1 → shown as one dog
- 6 + 3 = 9 → also one dog
- 7 + 9 = 16 → shown as dog–cat
- 11 + 17 = 28 → shown as cat–cat

Right column (from the picture):
- 0 + 2 = 2 → one cat
- 6 + 7 = 13 → dog–dog
- 11 + 12 = 23 → cat–dog

Notice two things:
1. The number of animal icons equals the number of digits of the sum.
2. Each digit is turned into an animal: odd digits give a dog, even digits give a cat.
   - 1 and 9 (odd) → dog (1-digit sums 1 and 9)
   - 2, 6, 8 (even) → cat
   - 16 → digits 1 (odd) and 6 (even) → dog–cat
   - 28 → digits 2 (even) and 8 (even) → cat–cat
   - 13 → 1 and 3 (both odd) → dog–dog
   - 23 → 2 (even), 3 (odd) → cat–dog

So the rule is:
- Each digit of the sum is replaced by:
  - dog if the digit is odd
  - cat if the digit is even

Now we want the smallest value of ? such that:

1 + ? = dog–dog–dog

That means the sum must be a three‑digit number, and **all three digits must be odd**.
The smallest three‑digit number whose every digit is odd is **111**.

So we need:
1 + ? = 111  ⇒  ? = 111 − 1 = 110.

There is no smaller option because any smaller sum is either not three digits or has at least one even digit, which would produce a cat instead of a dog.

Therefore, the smallest value for ? is 110.

answer: It’s impossible to pass through every doorway exactly once starting from the front door, so there is no room you can end up in under those conditions.
justification:
We can treat this as a graph (Euler path) problem: 
- Rooms are vertices.
- Doorways are edges between rooms (and one edge from the outside into the mansion).
- We must start at the front door, go through each doorway exactly once, and see where we *must* end up.

From the picture:
- The orange arrow at the bottom points into room **F** – that is the front entrance.
- Green lines show internal doorways. By following the walls you can count how many doorways (edges) each room has (its degree in graph terms):
  - Room A connects only into D by **one** doorway.
  - Room B connects into C and D by **two** doorways.
  - Room C connects into B and D by **two** doorways.
  - Room D is a central hub: it connects to A, B, C, E, and F by **five** doorways.
  - Room E connects into D and G by **two** doorways.
  - Room F connects into D, G, and the **front door from outside** by **three** doorways (two inside + one to outside).
  - Room G connects into E and F by **two** doorways.
- Count also the outside as a vertex; it has **one** connection (the front door) to F.

Now list the degrees:
- Outside: 1 (odd)
- A: 1 (odd)
- D: 5 (odd)
- F: 3 (odd)
- B, C, E, G: 2 (even)

In an undirected graph, an Eulerian trail (a path using each edge once) can exist only if there are **0 or 2 vertices of odd degree**. Here we have **four** (Outside, A, D, F), so **no path exists** which starts at the front door and passes each doorway exactly once. 

Since the stated condition (“pass through each doorway once and only once”) cannot be met at all, you can’t logically end up in any room: the task is impossible as given.

Therefore, the correct response to the test is to realize and state that the required walk cannot be done, i.e., there is *no* such final room to circle.

answer:
A = 1, B = 8, C = 4, D = 9, E = 5, F = 6, G = 2

The completed equation is:

18:49 × 3 = 56:27
justification:
Interpret the layout as a time equation:

    AB:CD × 3 = EF:G7

The letters A–G are distinct digits chosen from {1,2,4,5,6,8,9}. 7 and 3 are fixed.
Each pair to the left of a colon is minutes; each pair to the right is seconds.
So AB and EF are minutes, CD and G7 are seconds. Minutes and seconds must both be < 60.

Write everything in seconds:

- Left side: (60·AB + CD) × 3
- Right side: 60·EF + (10·G + 7)

Separating minutes and seconds gives:

1) Seconds: 3·CD = 60k + (10G + 7), for some carry k = 0,1,2 (since 3·59 = 177 < 180).
2) Minutes: 3·AB + k = EF.

### Step 1: Work out the seconds
The units digit on the right is 7, so 3·CD must end in 7.
Thus the seconds value CD must end in 9 (since 3×9 = 27 ends in 7), so D = 9.

Possible seconds values (0–59) ending in 9 are:
9, 19, 29, 39, 49, 59.

But the tens digit C must itself be a legal tens-of-seconds digit (0–5) and from our set {1,2,4,5,6,8,9}, disallowing 0 and 3. So CD can be:

- 19, 29, 49, 59.

Compute 3·CD for each:
- 3·19 = 57  → 0 min 57 s → k=0, seconds 57 → G=5.
- 3·29 = 87  → 1 min 27 s → k=1, seconds 27 → G=2.
- 3·49 = 147 → 2 min 27 s → k=2, seconds 27 → G=2.
- 3·59 = 177 → 2 min 57 s → k=2, seconds 57 → G=5.

Now apply the “no repeated digits” rule:
- CD=19 gives C=1, D=9, G=5 → digits {1,9,5} all distinct ✅
- CD=29 gives C=2, D=9, G=2 → C and G both 2 ❌
- CD=49 gives C=4, D=9, G=2 → digits {4,9,2} distinct ✅
- CD=59 gives C=5, D=9, G=5 → C and G both 5 ❌

So we can only have:
- Case A: CD=19, G=5, k=0
- Case B: CD=49, G=2, k=2

### Step 2: Check Case A (CD = 19, G = 5, k = 0)
Here k=0, so from the minutes equation:

    EF = 3·AB

Minutes EF must be < 60, so 3·AB < 60 → AB ≤ 19.

But the remaining digits (after using C=1,D=9,G=5) are {2,4,6,8}.
Minutes AB must use two of these, with the tens digit A ≤ 5, so A ∈ {2,4}.  That already forces AB ≥ 20. So AB cannot be ≤ 19.

Thus Case A is impossible.

### Step 3: Work with Case B (CD = 49, G = 2, k = 2)
Now:
- C = 4, D = 9, G = 2, and k = 2.
- Remaining digits for minutes (A,B,E,F) are {1,5,6,8}.

From the minutes equation:

    EF = 3·AB + 2

Again EF < 60, so

    3·AB + 2 ≤ 59  ⇒  3·AB ≤ 57  ⇒  AB ≤ 19.

Using digits {1,5,6,8} with no repetition, and remembering that minutes tens digits A and E must be at most 5, we have:
- A can be 1 or 5.
- But if A = 5, AB ≥ 50, contradicting AB ≤ 19.

So A = 1.
Then B can be 5, 6, or 8, giving possible AB:
- AB = 15, 16, 18.

Check each:
- AB=15 → 3·15+2 = 47. EF would be 47, but digits left for EF after using A,B,C,D,G are {5,6,8}; none give E=4, so impossible.
- AB=16 → 3·16+2 = 50. EF would need digits 5 and 0, but 0 is not available.
- AB=18 → 3·18+2 = 56. EF = 56.

For AB=18:
- Used digits now: A=1, B=8, C=4, D=9, G=2.
- Remaining digits: {5,6}.
- EF = 56 uses exactly {5,6}, with E=5 (tens of minutes), F=6.
- EF = 56 is a valid minutes value (< 60).

Everything fits:
- AB:CD = 18:49
- 3 × 18:49 = 56:27 (since 3×49 = 147 seconds = 2 min 27 s, and 3×18 + 2 = 56)

Check explicitly:
- 18:49 in seconds: 18×60 + 49 = 1080 + 49 = 1129.
- Tripled: 3×1129 = 3387 seconds.
- Convert back: 3387 ÷ 60 = 56 minutes, remainder 27 seconds → 56:27.
- Right-hand side format EF:G7 = 56:27 when E=5, F=6, G=2.

All seven digits 1,2,4,5,6,8,9 are used exactly once, and both times are under 60 minutes.

So the only consistent assignment is:
- A = 1
- B = 8
- C = 4
- D = 9
- E = 5
- F = 6
- G = 2

which gives the valid equation:

    18:49 × 3 = 56:27

Treat each little branch as a scale: the strings and sticks are weightless, and (from the drawing) each can hangs the same distance from the pivot on its branch. So whichever side of a branch hangs lower is the heavier side.

1. **Look at the three branches that have one can on each end:**
   - The bar with **B** and **C** is level.
   - The bar with **D** and **E** is level.
   - The bar with **G** and **H** is level.

   Since only *one* can is different (filled with water) and each of these three bars balances perfectly, each of these pairs must contain two cans of *equal* weight. Therefore none of B, C, D, E, G, or H is the special (heavier) can. All six of them must be empty.

2. **Now only A and F could possibly be the filled can.**

3. Check the *upper-left* branch (A vs. the B–C side): its right side (the side with B and C) hangs lower. But B and C are both empty, so that side is simply the weight of two empty cans. This tells us that two empty cans are heavier than whatever A is—but this is true whether A is empty or full, so this branch alone doesn’t decide between A and F.

4. Check the *upper-right* branch (F vs. the G–H side): here the **left side with F** hangs lower than the side with both G and H.
   - We already know G and H are empty, so the right side weighs exactly the same as **two empty cans**.
   - Yet the branch tilts down on F’s side, so the single can **F** is heavier than those two empty cans together.

   The only way one can can outweigh two known-empty cans is if **F** is the filled one. If any other can were filled instead, F would weigh the same as an empty can and could not possibly tip the branch down against the combined weight of G and H.

Therefore, the uniquely consistent choice is that **can F** is the one filled with water.

Let the capacities of the buckets be
- A = 3 gallons
- B = 4 gallons
- C = x gallons (what we want)
- D = y gallons
- E = z gallons.

From the picture:

• On the **2nd trip**, the woman carries buckets A, B, and D in one hand and buckets C and E in the other. Since the hands must balance,

    A + B + D = C + E
    3 + 4 + y = x + z
    7 + y = x + z        …(1)

• On the **3rd trip**, she carries buckets A and E in one hand and buckets C and D in the other. Again the hands balance, so

    A + E = C + D
    3 + z = x + y        …(2)

Now solve (1) and (2).

From (1): 7 + y = x + z
From (2): 3 + z = x + y

Subtract (2) from (1):

(7 + y) − (3 + z) = (x + z) − (x + y)
4 + y − z = z − y

Rearrange:

4 + y − z = z − y
4 + 2y = 2z
z = y + 2.

Substitute z = y + 2 into equation (2):

3 + (y + 2) = x + y
5 + y = x + y
x = 5.

So bucket C must hold **5 gallons** of water. (The other information in the puzzle allows you to determine D and E as well, but it isn’t needed to fix C.)

You spend a total of three hours from the moment you board a bus to the time you finish work: one hour riding to the office and two hours working.

For each choice of bus to work, compute when you finish, then look at the list of buses going home and pick the first one that leaves after that time.

Buses to work (left side):
- A: 4:00 a.m.
- B: 9:00 a.m.
- C: 2:30 p.m.
- D: 6:00 p.m.
- E: 12:00 a.m. (midnight)

Buses home (right side):
5:00 a.m., 10:30 a.m., 5:00 p.m., 8:00 p.m., 12:00 a.m. (midnight).

Now evaluate each possibility.

**Bus A**
- Leave: 4:00 a.m.
- Arrive at office: 5:00 a.m.
- Finish work: 7:00 a.m.
- Next bus home after 7:00 a.m.: 10:30 a.m.
- Wait: 3.5 hours.

**Bus B**
- Leave: 9:00 a.m.
- Finish work: 12:00 p.m.
- Next bus home after noon: 5:00 p.m.
- Wait: 5 hours.

**Bus C**
- Leave: 2:30 p.m.
- Finish work: 5:30 p.m.
- Next bus home after 5:30 p.m.: 8:00 p.m.
- Wait: 2.5 hours.

**Bus D**
- Leave: 6:00 p.m.
- Finish work: 9:00 p.m.
- Next bus home after 9:00 p.m.: 12:00 a.m. (midnight).
- Wait: 3 hours.

**Bus E**
- Leave: 12:00 a.m. (midnight).
- Arrive at office: 1:00 a.m.
- Finish work: 3:00 a.m.
- Next bus home after 3:00 a.m.: 5:00 a.m.
- Wait: 2 hours.

Among all options, the shortest waiting time for a bus home is 2 hours, which occurs if you take bus E to work.

Label the prices of a cup of tea, a glass of juice and a plate of toast as T, J and S, respectively. The total for each table is the same.

From table 1 and table 2:
- Table 1 has 3 juices and 2 toasts → 3J + 2S
- Table 2 has 2 teas and 2 toasts → 2T + 2S

Since the totals are equal:
3J + 2S = 2T + 2S  ⇒  3J = 2T.   (1)

From table 2 and table 3:
- Table 3 has 3 teas, 1 toast, and 1 juice → 3T + S + J

So:
2T + 2S = 3T + S + J  ⇒  S = T + J.   (2)

Thus, a plate of toast costs as much as one tea plus one juice.

Use (1) to express prices in terms of T:
3J = 2T  ⇒  J = (2/3)T.
Then from (2):
S = T + J = T + (2/3)T = (5/3)T.

Now calculate the common total (using, say, table 2):
Total = 2T + 2S = 2T + 2·(5/3 T) = 2T + 10/3 T = 16/3 T.

Table 4 currently shows 3 teas and 1 toast:
Current total at table 4 = 3T + S = 3T + 5/3 T = 14/3 T.

To reach 16/3 T, table 4 is short by:
16/3 T − 14/3 T = 2/3 T.
But 2/3 T is exactly the price of one juice (J).

Therefore, the missing item at table 4 must be a glass of juice.

So among the choices:
A: tea, B: juice, C: toast → the correct choice is B, a glass of juice.

Think about how the date is drawn in the watch’s little window.  
It uses a seven‑segment–style digital display, but in the small space of the window the two digits share the vertical bar that sits between them – there is only **one** central vertical segment there.

That shared bar has to be either lit or unlit for *both* digits at once; it can’t be on for the left digit but off for the right digit, or vice‑versa.

Now look at how the digits 3, 2, 6, 4 and 9 are written with seven‑segment style:

- **3** uses the vertical stroke on the *right* side of the digit but **no** vertical stroke on its left side.
- **2** uses that inner vertical stroke.
- **6** also uses it.
- **4** also uses it.
- **9** uses vertical strokes on *both* sides (left and right).

Because of the shared central bar:
- For **32**, both digits (3 and 2) want the middle shared bar lit. That’s fine – the bar is on for both, so 32 can be shown.
- For **64**, both digits (6 and 4) also want the middle shared bar lit, so 64 can also be shown.
- For **93**, however, the left digit **9** wants the shared bar lit (it has a vertical on that side), but the right digit **3** wants that side *off* (3 has no vertical bar on its left side). With only one shared segment there is no way to satisfy both at once:  
  • If the bar is **on**, the 3 gains an extra vertical stroke and looks like a 9.  
  • If the bar is **off**, the 9 loses a stroke and looks like a 3.

So the watch cannot display a clear “93” at all – that combination is impossible on this display, whereas 32 and 64 can be made.

Therefore, among A (32), B (93), and C (64), the number that could never actually appear on this watch is **B**.
